places_url_reviews_title: A must place for every one traveling in the area.
places_url_reviews_comment: The Hill AF museum is an exellent Aeronautical museum, for every on. Every time i am trveling in the are i must save some time to visit the Hill museum. The outside and inside exibit Airplanes are wonderfull and kept in a very good condition. Eveery one can learn about the fighters and bombers used during the WW2, Vietnam and later wars. A MUST point to visit in Ogden area.

places_url_reviews_title: "Off we went . . . into the Wild Blue Yonder!"
places_url_reviews_comment: Wow! Huge selection of WWI through present-day aircraft, both inside and outside the museum, all perfectly displayed. Plenty of informative signage to learn about each plane and accompanying paraphernalia. Knowledgable and friendly retired airmen (?) available to answer any question. Large and well-stocked gift shop, too. We really enjoyed our visit!

I'm not a military or aviation fanatic, but I did enjoy walking through the exhibits. There's lots to see indoor if it's too hot to walk through the outdoor exhibit. There's a scavenger hunt to keep young kids interested.

places_url_reviews_title: Best air and space museum west of the Smithsonian.
places_url_reviews_comment:
What a find! An incredible collection of aircraft from throughout history, along with memorabilia, artifacts and placards to explain it all.
Spread across two large hangers and outdoors, this place is incredible - and free (other than your tax dollars). Wear comfortable walking shoes for these concrete floors.
A must-see for any air buff.

I am an airplane junkie. I love getting to go to museums that have anything to do space and aerospace. While this pales in comparison to other museums size wise, it is still definitely worth a visit. For me this was a trip down memory lane. The aircraft that are indoors are very well preserved and cared for. While there are some items that have displays explaining what the items are, there are some that are not labeled. There is a very descriptive display for our heroes that served in Vietnam. The museum is free to visit although there are plenty of donation boxes around the museum. The staff do not bug you about contributions. The staff are also very friendly and want to help. Like I said, it is definitely worth a visit if you have any interest in aircaraft.

places_url_reviews_title: A highlight of our Salt Lake City area visit
places_url_reviews_comment: What an amazing collection of historic planes. A must see for anyone interested in military history or airplanes. Well worth the trip to Ogden.

Outstanding display of aviation history in the military services. The aircraft are displayed so that you can observe them, and there are volunteers to answer questions.
I am a retired Coast Guard Officer, and the gift shop had more Coast Guard "stuff" than any Coast Guard Exchange.....and I bought at least one of each item they were selling.

Today was our first ever visit to this museum and we were absolutely thankful we found it!! The displays of military planes were wonderful and informative. The volunteers were great with some wonderful historical knowledge of facts about the military planes in the museum. The gift shop had a wonderful variety of items to purchase from toy planes to clothing. Highly recommend this place for families and aviation fans, especially when you’re able to enjoy everything at no cost!!!

I can't believe this place is free. I would happily pay but am so thankful it is free. My husband LOVES jets/planes, etc. My son also really enjoyed it and I did too. I learned SO much. The staff was so very helpful and I was blown away by their knowledge. They really go above and beyond to make guests understand what they are looking at.
We bought some things from the gift shop, the staff in the shop was so friendly and helpful too.
After we spent an hour or so in the museum we ate outside at a picnic table (I packed lunch) and it was REALLY fun to eat as a family under the wing of jet. If you are even slightly interested in jets/planes you will have a ball here!

places_url_reviews_title: F117 Stealth Fighter added to their collection!
places_url_reviews_comment: An excellent air museum with a very large and well-maintained collection. They received an F117 in August 2020 and it is being restored on the museum floor in full view of visitors.

We really enjoyed visiting the museum, it has beautiful displays and aircraft. Admission was free, so that's a plus! You can walk around at you own pace, and the volunteers are nice and full of great information. There is plenty to see outside, and they have picnic tables available. It was very clean, and they are following covid protocols so bring your mask. Google map sends you to the wrong exit FYI, so get the address from somewhere else.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the best air museums I have had the pleasure to tour
places_url_reviews_comment:
One of the best air museums I have had the pleasure to tour. Two inside galleries and a large exterior display.
And it was free.
Highly recommend

If you are even remotely interested in airplanes and airplane history you have to come see the Hill Aerospace Museum!!
The exhibits are beyond fascinating. Dozens of historical planes, recent historic planes and planes of today. All are in extremely great condition.
In addition to the planes there are also wheeled vehicles, sample uniforms from days gone by, and stories about famous airmen.
Are also docents around the museum willing to talk to you about any of the exhibits; and extremely knowledgeable.
There are both inside and outside exhibits.
I was there for 3 hours and it seemed like I had been there for about 15 minutes. Dozens of photos and some great memories.
I highly suggest a visit to Hill Aerospace Museum if you are anywhere with in a hundred miles of Ogden, Utah!!

I first went to this museum 34 years ago when it was a few aircraft parked on the west side of Hill Air Force Base. I just went back and the museum is fantastic. The planes, information, and displays were great. I would highly recommend a visit. There is a lot of space in the museum so you never feel too crowded inside or outside.

places_url_reviews_title: A good museum, but is like most other plane museums.
places_url_reviews_comment: A pleasant aerospace museum showcasing some vintage planes, most under roof. You get very close to the planes. Because of COVID you can't get into the cockpits of the ones that they normally open cockpits for. This is an average museum and in my opinion falls into the "if you've seen one aerospace museum you've seen them all" category. It's not much different than other typical plane museums. It is on Hill AFB but you don't go on base. The museum is very clean and kept up very nicely. We made a special trip up that way to see it and it really wasn't worth it because it's just another plane museum. Still, if you live nearby, or in the area and want to find a place to kill a few hours with the kids, this will do it for sure.
This falls in the must see category. Two hangers plus an open area. Documents both aviation history and us battles. Takes an hour to view longer for in depth. Easy on and off the freeway.
The outside static display when you first arrive is very interesting with wonderful signage that gave lots of interesting facts about the aircraft

places_url_reviews_title: You are close enough to touch the planes, but don’t!
places_url_reviews_comment: You can walk right up to and under a lot of the planes and are close enough to touch them but multiple signs tell you not to. There are planes from the beginning of aviation to F 16s. All are meticulously restored and are innovatively displayed. There are many informative explanations and details posted. The volunteers were helpful and friendly. If you like planes you need to visit. And it is free.

Lots of planes both indoor and outside with information about each one, sometimes with a Utah focus as Hill AFB is next door. We only had 90 minutes so no time to watch videos or special topics in side rooms. This is a very nice place and well worth 2-3 hrs of adult time, probably less with kids.

places_url_reviews_title: So much to see, learn and experience... and it's FREE
places_url_reviews_comment: Great free activity to see. So many cool planes to look at, amazing history to learn, and you get to be right up next to some of the coolest flying machines in existence. Can't ask for much better

This Museum is great for young and old. It is free but they have places to donate and as good as this is you will want to donate some. The volunteers are very helpful and will take you on a guided tour if you like. It is arranged in a way that you start at the beginning of our military aviation on up to today. There is a lot of tributes to local heroes even some of their uniforms are on display. There are a lot of excellent static examples from bi-planes to SR - 71s, F16’s, B 52, C 124’s and even a B29 and more. I highly recommend this museum.

Here is a museum with everything from the Air Forse. Can you imagine seeing a Blackbird supersonic airplane up close? There is also a B-36 which was restored from the West Desert where the atom bomb aviators were trained, right here in Utah. Inside the museum there is everythingn from a Wright Flyer replica to all the great fighters of the wars. Don't take my word, just GO! Yes, it is FREE, but please donate to the cause in one of the money bins.

As we travel, we have seen several aerospace museums. This one is smaller than others we have seen and does not have the quantity that those places have, but it is still very nice and has an impressive collection. There is a film you can watch, and there are two main indoor areas with planes and helicopters to see. Some are hanging and many are on the floor. They are labeled so you know their significance. Then they have a nice number of aircraft outside that you can walk along the sidewalk to see up close. They also have a small gift shop inside. We spent about an hour and a half here and felt that was sufficient. If you just love airplanes and want to read all the display information, you will want more time. As I think back on our visit here, I remember this small boy there with some other men in his family. He just kept saying “Whoa!” as he saw all these large aircraft. So that should tell you that the displays are impressive. Enjoyable visit and you can’t beat the price...free! And free parking!
Great museum with outdoor and indoor aircraft in absolutely pristine condition. By the way admission is free! Volunteers throughout are very helpful and there are interactive exhibits as well.

The grandkids love to visit the museum. My youngest grandson has even memorized the freeway exit to the museum. They are allowed to go into the planes, sit in the pilot seat, etc. We could spend more time than I usually have with them.

This was a great stop. Hill has an amazing collection of flight! They even have a display dedicated to the women flyers of WWII. The docents are engaging and informative. I could spend hours just hearing their stories.

places_url_reviews_title: Grand Kids at the Hill Aerospace Museum
places_url_reviews_comment: We took our grandkids to Hill Aerospace Museum. The boy is 6and his sister is 2, when asked what they liked best about the museum, the oldest said he liked running around looking at all the planes outside, while the younger one said she liked the inside best. We enjoyed both!

I had the greatest time here.it was so interesting following air planes from there beginning to the current airplanes out there. seeing the need for speed increased as new technology progressed. The greatest part was seeing actual airplanes of each era. I would definitely recommend it to those interested in History of Flight.

This was one of many times we have enjoyed the Air Museum. I started taking my grandchildren there 20 years ago. The museum itself is a treasure so give yourself time to explore both buildings and outside. It closes early afternoon so be there at least by noon. I’ll always have memories of the excitement my grandchildren showed as they looked up at all the planes - one grandson always had to be lifted up to touch the SR71. One very special time was watching my father and father-in-law reminisce about their days working on airplanes at Douglas Air Force Base. They love this place! I hope you will take time to see an amazing place, I know you will love it.

Great for budget minded folks and anyone that has respect for our military and wonderment of the ability to take flight.
Take your kids, on a date, with family and friends and celebrate! Not uncommon to see military vets there offering information.
It’s a good place to be an American. Take time to go to Hill AFB. Pay respect and stand in awe of the amazing machines and museum collections of memorabilia because..... we must never forget!

If you needed a reason to visit this place, it's the nicest ones I have ever seen.
It housed all the jets and planes I read about and watched in movies.
F15 from top gun, the Lockheed SR-71 Blackbird, my favorite plane.
A10 warthog etc etc.
The planes outside before you go inside is crazy too. I made a special trip to Utah and lucked out to see this place.
Go see it see it now.
As a side note there was a gentleman there who I spoke with who told me some amazing war stories again worth the time to talk to the vets.

places_url_reviews_title: Best free aviation museum in the Intermountain West
places_url_reviews_comment: This place is a real treat with indoor and outdoor displays. The volunteer staff have either work experience on the display planes or are just truly enthusiastic aviation buffs that know their planes. Can easily spend half a day or more here and there are plenty of restaurants and other attractions nearby.

I have visited many air museums, and this would rank near the top. They have an extensive collection, dating from a 1911 Wright model f up through a b1b. They were a true Air Force museum, having only a couple of migs that were not part of the UAAF. What stood out was the placard that explained how each airplane was connected to Hill AFB. They also had a great exhibit of modifications invented at Hill. Well worth a visit. And it’s free!

places_url_reviews_title: See incredible aircraft from various time periods
places_url_reviews_comment: This place doesn't charge a fee to enter, though I'm sure donations are appreciated. Walk through the museum to see the history of aircraft used in multiple military operations through the ages. You can easily spend an hour or more here. It's great for the family and even offers a learning center for a more interactive experience.

We took our grandson's to this museum of aircraft. It was interesting. People can move at their own pace and see a lot about aircraft and planes. There are several interactive displays and the gift shop was a hit with our grandson's. Good for kids four and older.
This was a very interesting place to go and the kids actually enjoyed it quite a bit. It's free admission so you don't have much to lose by trying it out. Definitely a lot of history.
We brought a large group here for the first time. I have been to a few aerospace museums and this one is top notch. It is free admission.

I have been to a few AFB museums and I have to say this is probably one of the best ones I have seen. The quantity and quality of aircraft here is very impressive. One can easily spend a few hours and probably not see everything or miss some of the side displays. They also have veterans here that are more than happy to show you around.
Been here many times. Lots of stuff to see. Great for kids. Can spend hours here if you like to read about everything.

A visit here should not be missed.
You will feel respect and gratitude for our service people and patriotism for the USA.
My kids love going here from time to time. It's nice they move things around and my kids could spend all day here.

Well worth the drive if you are in the Salt Lake area. The outdoor planes are very well maintained for the environment they live in. The indoor exhibits were awesome. They are very well displayed and explained. The staff of volunteers are very friendly and helpful with any questions you may have. This is a very valuable asset to the area and they make it available for free..

places_url_reviews_title: Good for younger kids and older ones too.
places_url_reviews_comment: If you are into aircraft give this a look. It has some neat stuff there. Worth seeing at least once if in the area. I found my children when they were around 8 to 10 fasinated but teens unless it's third thing we're not into it.

places_url_reviews_title: Must see when in Layton UT
places_url_reviews_comment: Great museum and well worth our 2 hour visit. If you have a veteran with Vietnam or Korea memories they will surely agree that it is very well presented along with lots of planes on display. Good WWII displays as well.
Brilliant collection of aircraft and wonderfully knowledgeable staff. This was our second visit, it's well worth spending time here.
Our two boys (ages 8 and 3) love planes, so this was a great stop during our stay in Salt Lake City. It's free and includes both indoor and outdoor exhibits.

This museum is so much fun! The exhibits besides the planes themselves are so well done. So much to see, you could spend all day there. I love looking at the fighter jets and imagine what they would be like streaking across the sky in battle. Not to be missed and it’s free, but donations are accepted throughout.
If you are a military or plane buff this is the place for you! Very informative and the staff is very knowledgeable and willing to share their stories
What an amazing Aerospace Museum. We have have two small children and they loved looking at all of the planes. Thank you to all the men and women who has served our country.

What a great variety of planes.
It was a great visit and I my son had a wonderful time. I would take my friends
This museum is free to visit. Please make a small donation. What a great place to learn about history / planes and jets. SR71 is amazing.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the best aerospace museums I have been too.
places_url_reviews_comment: Several large sections with all kinds of aircraft. Small exhibits too, such as aircraft engines. Displays inside, large aircraft are outside. You cannot enter outside aircraft. Clean, neat, and good stories on individual aircraft. I got there when it opened so no one was around except the docents who were very good at explaining about any subject I brought up in detail. The docents made this visit memorable. I will go back.

This is an incredible museum relating to flight - particularly military. It is huge - planes inside two huge buildings and planes outside. We wish we had had more time to spend there. There is so much to see and learn. Very accessible for all ages. And it is free.
Great place to take the kids and grand kids. They have aircraft from very early eras, world wars, and cold war era. Very enjoyable.

This is an amazing museum. There are incredible and unique flying machines. Children are in awe, both boys and girls. It is a great tribute to our Air Force and Mamés me proud to be an American. If you are in the area, it is a must seee for everyone. You will not be disappointed.
Took the Kids and grandkids for a fun filled adventure day.This is an excellent museum with a great variety of aircraft and a pleasant, knowlegable staff.

With free admission the only sacrifice is time, and it’s time well spent. Lots of large fully intact planes right outside of the museum to see and walk around. Lots of planes inside to see, with a few helicopters to walk into. More planes then I could count, and lots of history about the military base surrounding the Vietnam, Korean, and Gulf wars. Lots of memorials for fallen soldiers and veterans. Great place to spend an afternoon or weekend visit. Will return again in the future, it’s just right off I-15 so very easy to navigate to from the freeway.

This is an excellent museum for those that love to get up close to a large variety of military planes. Most planes are inside two large hanger type buildings which makes it suitable for inclement weather days. The larger planes are located outside on an easily walkable site. This is a good spot to take the kids, both young and old alike. There is no admission fees.

Very comprehensive museum with lots to see and experience. The staff is first class and very accomodating. I watched how they handled student groups and young children and it was really cool. They care about the experience that everyone is having.

Excellent history and displays. A must see for aviation history buffs. We read a story about a pilot who saved his Crew and made it safely back to base after a crippling attack on his B-17. The Fightin’ Hebe. The article impressed us so much we researched the history later that evening.

places_url_reviews_title: Top Tier Museum Experience, and Free
places_url_reviews_comment:
The kids liked it. The parents liked it. The grandparents liked it.
The exhibits are on a par with the Smithsonian Air and Space Museum, and varied in point of view. History, design, humanity and science, all mixed together. Just a cool place. Recommended.
Mini old planes, very well laid out most are all indoors, great to visit when weather is bad outside won’t be disappointed if you like old airplanes

Very impressive amount of planes and no one mission for you very helpful and knowledgable volunteer staff well worth the trip it was a bit windy and cool during the day we were there so all the outside plants and then a large amount of planes inside very impressive worth two hours and we had
Very cool place to visit - every time I go there I find something new and interesting. Also a great place to take out of town guests,

This place is amazing. The collection is very extensive from helicopters, small military aircraft to large aircraft. Most of the planes are indoors except for a few. They have been restored mostly by voluteers from Hill Airforce Base. The volunteers who are there are just as interesting if not more interesting than the planes themselves.

Had a good leasure walk reading and interacting with many wonderful exhibits (planes & set up viewing areas). Recommend lightweight clothing during summer indoors get warm and outdoors in the sun a while. Wholesome for every age group - and free. Highly recommend taking a few dollars for
Donations.
We took small children and they loved it! There’s even an education/craft room where a volunteer help our kids build paper helicopters

I enjoy visiting aerospace and flight museums and have had to pleasure of seeing good ones from coast to coast. One of the best is right here in Utah in our own backyard. Well organized and accessible displays. Lectures and historical events throughout the year. Knowledgeable docents always handy and first class shop. Plenty of handy free parking. Did I mention? FREE admission.

places_url_reviews_title: If you love airplanes, you'll love this museum
places_url_reviews_comment: It's been a few years since I've been to the Hill Aerospace Museum, but it was pretty amazing. Got to see the blackbird stealth aircraft. Great!!
This is a great museum and its free!! I take the grand kids often. I am a private pilot and enjoy seeing these significant historical aircraft.
This museum is rich in military history. If you love planes, this is a perfect place to go! It is free but do accept donations!

It's a very intersting place with a lot of history. For me it was a fantastic day. But my wife was facinated too.
There was one unforgetable moment... we come in one of halls with the machines of the past - used in war ... and we talked with some veteran, who stand next to an large engine: Well, I remember - this one was allways a bit tricky to keep it running - but I made it... He explained us all the details and the "real life hacks" ... It was amazing!

First and foremost this is a great military aircraft museum. There are planes from World War I, World War II, the Korean War, the Vietnam War, the Gulf War as well as a small jet used by President Lyndon Johnson painted in the Air Force One colors as well as a an F-16 flown by the Thunderbirds. Almost 100 airplanes are on display in two indoor galleries and an outdoor airpark. Parking is free and admission is free, however there are locked containers throughout the museum to make a donation. The hours of operation are Mon-Sat, 9:00 am - 4:30 pm. They close the gates promptly at 4:30 pm. The museum is staffed by volunteers, many ex-military, who are happy to share information and stories from their time in the service.
Upon entering the museum you can pick up a map of the facility and stop into the small theater that has short films that, run on a continuous loop, on various aspects of the US Air Force. In the museum itself the planes have a narrative on the plane itself as well as some interesting notes. In addition to planes, there are helicopters, military vehicles, a replica of the first atomic bomb detonated, code name Trinity, as well as other decommissioned ordinance. There are also several areas with short videos set up to give a more in-depth experience to the visitor.
Some of the more special planes of interest to me were the C-130 Military Transport Plane, the B-29 Superfortress from World War II and Korean War fame, the B-52 Stratofortress (which is still in use today), the B-1 Bomber (a supersonic heavy bomber), the SR-71 Blackbird a strategic reconnaissance aircraft used primarily for covert aerial reconnaissance and a MiG-21 Russian built supersonic interceptor also used by China, North Vietnam, India, Croatia and Romania.
There is a gift shop by the entrance selling books, tee shirts, jackets, snacks and other souvenir gifts. It takes a good 2 1/2 hours minimum to see everything and read about the history of the planes but if you just want to do a quick walk through you can do it in less time. You cannot touch the planes or sit inside them but you can take as many pictures as you want. If you have any interest in planes utilized by the US Air Force and want to get a good look at many of them, this is definitely a place to visit and as stated before , the price can't be beaten, even with a monetary donation.

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to see military aircraft
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a fun place to visit and see a large quantity of military aircraft, including SR-71 Blackbird. Kids of all ages will love spending hours touring the planes which are inside and outside.

This museum was beyond my expectations. They have the exhibits arranged by era, WWI, WWII, Korea, Vietnam, etc. There are obviously planes, but what I didn't expect was the jeeps, missiles, and bombs also included with plane exhibits. It's really cool to be able to see all of it up close and personal. Many of the planes are much larger than I expected. Among the exhibits, there are several eyewitness accounts and quotes, some with actual recordings of first-hand experiences.
Great planes and jets. It was worth the trip for the SR-71 Blackbird and to read about it. What an unbelievable jet for its era.

The place is packed with all kinds of airplanes. The outside area has some huge planes, it’s free to enter, but you are welcome to donate if you wish to. They got some craft activities for smaller children.

I live out of state, but when we come back to visit family, we often stop in here so my kids can run around and look at cool planes. It's fun to see, but this time I think the novelty is wearing off for my kids. It's hard to complain about a free museum though... In the summer, these hangars are SO HOT inside so be ready for that. We like the SR-71 blackbird, the helicopters, and the F-16 the most. There's a pretty nice gift shop to browse too. If you have little kids, I recommend a stroller.

This museum would be worth paying admission to...but it's free. If you are into aviation and military aviation history, you'll love this place. There are many various aircraft that have been restored by the folks at the attached Air Force Base and a plethora of exhibits showing uniforms and flight suits and other aviation artifacts plus informative historical tidbits.

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to learn air force history and see the real plane
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum is amazing with a lot of true Air Force plane from all different era. And they do not charge for entry. A great spot when doing road trip on interstate 15. Very close to interstate.

places_url_reviews_title: A great and information aviation museum
places_url_reviews_comment:
This morning we drove north on Fwy I-14 from Salt Lake City and left the freeway at Exit 338.
Our destination was the Hill Aerospace Museum on the north side of Hill Air Force Base. The museum is quite spectacular and very informative. They have a lot of aircraft, about 72 all told. About 50 are located inside and the balance are located outside. The aircraft included fighters, bombers, helicopters and passenger/cargo aircraft and were either piston or jet engine powered. All the aircraft were military, no civilian passenger planes. Most of the aircraft has been serviced at Hill AFB. In addition to the aircraft, there are a number of drones and missiles.
There was NO charge to tour the Museum. There is a gift shop but no canteen (restaurant) on site.
There is so much to see that we went back a second day. This time, we walked by all the outside aircraft.
It was well worth the visit as our returning to complete our tour reflected.

places_url_reviews_title: Fantastic museum if you like airplanes and/or military history.
places_url_reviews_comment: This was a pleasant surprise on the grounds of Hill AirForce Base outside of Ogden, Utah. They have so many planes and aircraft, both inside and outside. There are 10-15 planes outside, including a stealth bomber and B52. Inside there are two large hangars filled with aircraft, bombs and other military memorabilia. Great way to send a couple hours.

I've been to the "biggie" the National Museum of the US Air Force at Wright Patterson AFB near Riverside, Ohio. The Hill museum is much smaller, but everything else is, including the NASA Museum at the Smithsonian in Washington, DC.
The Hill museum has an incredible collection, including a Lockheed SR-71 Blackbird. There are few "antique" planes, but the aircraft are a marvel to see.
If you go, plan on taking at least an hour. If you are a buff, plan on three or four hours and you may have enough time to inspect and appreciate the great aircraft.
One little display, often overlooked is in a small case to the west side of one building. The glass case contains a couple of photos of a man, Vern Moncur, along with his flight jacket. He was a member of the crew called "Hell's Angels." No, not a motorcycle gang, but the crew of a B-17 bomber that served in the European theater.
I have been to the museum a few times, but I never have enough time, so I end up returning, only to run out of time on each visit.
If you are an airplane or Air Force buff, no matter what you're looking for, you'll find something that will catch your eye and stop you in your tracks.
This is a great place to visit, to bring your children or grandchildren. It will inspire awe in them if you take the time to tell what these aircraft were, what they were used for, and how they changed the tide of history.

They just had a large open house this past weekend, and it was packed. My wife and I play with the Ogden City Concert Band and had the pleasure to play for this. It was something that was important to Honor and pay Homage to the Veterans that have served our country in the past, present and the future. They have been able to collect some of the most impressive planes and other military items in our history. And you have a chance to learn about how the items there served to protect us. It is very mush worth the time to spend several hours looking at each item and read about it. Imagine at that time what brave men and women took to the air or on the ground to defend our country.

We visited the Aerospace Museum today. It was very well done. It had easy access just off the interstate, Admission was free. Outside displays were very interesting and you were able to walk among the planes. Inside the museum had many restored exhibits. The were very well done. A variety of aircraft and individual exhibits were very informative. I've been to several military museums and this wasn't the best but it was good. I'm glad I went.

My first visit was in 1989 when it was 100% outdoors. I returned in July 2014 when most of the aircraft had been moved indoors. It's like still a good bet. Most of the displays are from WW2 and later. Lately I can't get Travel Advisor from shoving this in my face even though it's technically too old for me to review.

places_url_reviews_title: A Must See for Aviation & History Enthusiasts, and Families Too
places_url_reviews_comment:
I agree with the previous 4 and 5 Rating Reviews, so I will just add a few additional observations.
The museum is on an active Air Force base, so in addition to static displays you may get to watch F-35s fly around during your visit, which we did (I could do that all day....). Like several others mentioned I have visited many aviation museums, and Hill Aerospace Museum makes the cut for those I want to visit several more times. I need several days - a few hours are not enough really. Many docents are on-site and there a lot of activities for children.
The aircraft outside are not restored, but I must say that I like to see these planes in the 'normal' condition they were in when in service and / or recovered. This really gives a perspective on how challenging the conidtions were for the airman and ground crews, and an appreciation of the very hard work needed to restore the aircraft to museum quality.
And admission is free, unlike most of the other better museums, but I still left a nice donation equal to the admission at other museums.

Every child should go with their parents and visit this museum. Not only do you get to see the Technological Marvels of Flight, you get a great history lesson. Retired military personnel are also there to entertain you with events. If you are near the area, you must stop by and the best part is--there is no fee--but they always accept any donation. It was fun to see the airplane type that my father had flown.

places_url_reviews_title: Great family time- and it's free!
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum is HUGE. There are so many wonderful planes, parts, uniforms, and historical information all in one area. The grounds are maintained beautifully. Airplanes are displayed inside and out. And on some weekends they have interactive activities for kids at no cost. You can easily spend a couple of hours here. My kids have been visiting for years. I have paid $20 a person for other aerospace museums that offer far less than this. Great way to get out of the house and learn something any time of year. And if you can- be sure and drop a few dollars in the donation box to say thanks.

We were surprised to find that we were able to tour this museum at absolutely no cost. We spent several hours there, first looking at the large number of airplanes that are displayed outside, and then going through the various exhibits that are well laid out in the interior. Although we are not real aviation buffs, we spent an informative and interesting few hours here.

places_url_reviews_title: This is a "must see" when visiting the Odgen area
places_url_reviews_comment: We visited the Aerospace Museum. We were really impressed with the airplanes that they had on display. There are several aircraft outside - there is two hangers that contain various military aircraft. The docents are friendly and very knowledgeable. The docents will give you a map of the museum, which we found very helpful. Very interesting to see how aviation has improved over time.

places_url_reviews_title: See the History of Military Aviation
places_url_reviews_comment: The first thing to remember is that this Museum is on an Air Force Base, so the amenities are sufficient but not outstanding. The interior display is well presented and many of the WWII and Korean war fighters are present. Space is limited so the planes overlap to a degree. The exterior displays are subject to the elements and show it a bit.

Regular price is free. But seriously, this is a great museum with incredible static displays. There is a large outdoor area representing all eras. The two indoor displays, one focused on Vietnam Nam era and the other,mostly Korean and WWII tributes.
They also provide motorized chairs for those who find it difficult to walk the display areas. Takes about 1-3 hours, depending on your interest in flight memorabilia.
Awesome museum and lots to see. The best part is that’s is free. Much history here, inside and out. Good for kids.

places_url_reviews_title: Awesome to see all the old planes!
places_url_reviews_comment: It is gigantic, planes inside hangers and out. Worth seeing if you have never been there. They have lots of planes. Historical planes as well as the newer Stealth plane. Wear your tennis shoes, will be lots of walking.

Having visited the National Museum of the United States Air force in Dayton Ohio many times, I had low expectations. I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and quantity of the collections. The museum is arranged in historical order and offers something from every era of military aviation. The POW exhibit is very moving. Allow a minimum of three to four hours to see everything.

The aerospace museum offers so much on the history of aviation that adults can go and learn something new, but there are so many cool and colorful planes of all shapes and sizes that the kids loved it! My boys were mesmerized.

I say great for kids but really its my husband who gets so excited to go see all the planes. Like a kid in a candy store. I love thats its FREE and open to the public. Getting up so close to many of the planes is very cool.

Have lived in the area for years and treasure this gem. Dropped in from Salt Lake since I had a business meeting in Ogden. The size of the collection and presentation is impressive. Expansion building houses fighter jets, war memorabilia, and humbling tributes to POW's. Numerous aircraft outside catch your attention from the highway. Visited on a weekday shortly after opening. Many visitors were already on sight including a tourists from China. Vets and military service people are typically on sight either at information desks and among visitors since this museum sits near an active military base. Depending on the time of year you can also catch sight of fighter jets flying above the area all through Roy and Ogden. There is a great deal to see and amazing history documented throughout. Plenty of parking, gift shop inside, clean, very friendly people, donations are asked for though not mandatory.

places_url_reviews_title: Need to visit when in the area
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum really is a pearl in the area! The museum does not only show the different technical stages in aerospace aviation but also the power of the USAF. A must do when in the area. Hill Aerospace Museum is located on the northwest corner of Hill Air Force Base, Utah. Open Monday- Saturday 9:00 a.m. until 4:30 p.m and admission is Free to the Public. The Museum has close to 100 aircraft displayed in its two inside galleries and outside air park.

It was fun to get up close to the aircraft. Lots of history here. I especially enjoyed seeing the SR-71 that is the fasted airplane ever built. It could fly from Washington, DC to Los Angeles in a little over an hour. Also like the F-16s. I couldn’t believe how big a F-15 was. Two nice galleries indoors with planes from WWII to Vietnam Nam. Also some large planes outside like the C124 and the B-52. Plan on an hour to two hours to see everything. The price is great - it’s free, but there are donation boxes throughout, so put a Dollar in each box. Great fun!
My wife, my son and I use to go here all the time. I wish it had some more interactive displays. SR71 Blackbird.
Our family had a great visit to this museum with an incredible collection! There are both indoor and outdoor areas of this museum.

places_url_reviews_title: Well worth the visit if you can Overlook one minor issue
places_url_reviews_comment:
The museum itself is outstanding. Every aircraft is well-documented and provides more than enough information and history on each aircraft. There is a section on the Hanoi Hilton that is very real realistic with many real world artifacts.
The only problem I had was in the gift shop where the cashier was too busy on the phone to let me cash out. I walked out without making a purchase. Other than that it's a great museum that should not be missed.
This place is a great place to visit! So much history! I would love to come again but it will have to be in the cooler weather. It was super hot outside and very warm inside.

Whether you love aircraft, military hardware, or are just looking for an amazing place to spend 1 to 4 hours this is the place for you. Some of the larger aircraft are located outside and you can get up close and personal with these monsters. Inside the two main hangers there are many many aircraft from the Wright Brothers through very modern fighter aircraft. You can get closer than you will ever get to any military aircraft in the world. The Hill Aerospace Museum I feel closely rivals the Wright Patterson museum. If you are local or visiting you really should plan to spend some time here. Admission is free and the museum is located just off I-15 Roy exit. Great for all ages
We really enjoyed all the exhibits in the museum. The outside and inside are a must. It's hard to believe it's free!! There is a gift shop also.
Hill has some amazing airplanes, learned a bit of history while just browsing and having a good time.

If you like military aviation then this quite simply is a "Must do". There is a wonderful collection outside as well as two large halls inside. There is pretty war to just about modern day and classics like the F-86, F-100, F-105 through to the F-16 plus the SR-71.
All aircraft are in excellent condition and we'll maintained. You will need a flashgun for your camera as lighting is sadly poor and should be improved in my opinion. It's open 9am to 4:30pm and is free entry.

Wonderful museum full of military aircraft. When we were there there were several old WWII veterans sitting next to the planes they flew and they were telling of their experiences flying those planes during the war. They even have a Blackbird. Excellent experience! Highly recommend!
My dad loves airplanes and each time they would visit we would go. And the volunteers are great! Will definitely go again!

My husband loves this museum and has visited it multiple times (we live in Washington). It can be overwhelming, but luckily it is free! We went just after school let out; I'm sure it's a great venue for kids as they can eat a sack lunch outside and have free admission. It was nice to see dads and grandpas visiting with their young family members. The WASP exhibit was great, very informative.
The directions were easy to locate from either the Ogden side or Roy.

This was a great museum for local aviation history on Hill AFB. It was free and had a great display of aircraft that had been stationed or maintained at Hill.
Military retirees volunteered at the museum. They were full of information and stories.
The two things I loved most were: 1. the variety of the aircraft, the travel through aviation history from WWI to present. 2. The inclusion of women in aviation history including the WASPS; and 3 the accessibility of the aircraft.
I would definitely recommend going a trip to Hill Aerospace museum.

places_url_reviews_title: GREAT PLACE TO VISIT FOR A TOY PLANE COLLECTOR AS WELL
places_url_reviews_comment: My husband loves to collect toy plane and when we went to this place, he was amazed and can't get enough. The museum was unbelievable, very educational and informative. I haven't seen planes like those big in one place. It's a must to see when in Ogden, Utah.

places_url_reviews_title: Great collection of aircraft inside and out, for free!
places_url_reviews_comment:
This is one of the most complete aerospace museums I have seen. Having been in an different branch of service I was not familiar with all the USAF aircraft, and some aviation history.
It has a very nice area for UT avation history, and a great exhibit about the WASPs from WW II.

places_url_reviews_title: Over a Century of US Air Power on Display
places_url_reviews_comment:
An impressive collection of USAF aircraft spanning a century of aviation. The museum is made up of two hangers and an outside area where the larger aircraft are displayed. All aircraft have accompanying information panels and the hangers tell the story of American air power from WWI up to the modern day. The aircraft are maintained in excellent condition and knowledgeable and enthusiastic museum volunteers are on hand to answer any questions you may have.
Entry is free but I’d strongly recommend you make a donation - this museum is a labour of love and well worth a visit!

I visited to use up time before cheering my friend at the Ogden marathon finish. Hill AFB is conveniently located near the finish line to go to the museum and thoroughly read through the displays and peruse the outdoor exhibits.
The indoor displays and visual reader boards were very professionally laid out. Lots of information that was not too overwhelming. Gift shop had an amazing selection.

places_url_reviews_title: Great museum! Free to the public with a lot to see.
places_url_reviews_comment: I was very pleasantly surprised by the museum. The exhibits were well tended and there were interesting plaques with great information on them. Each plane had a story and an interesting bit of history about them. The staff was phenomenal, friendly and helpful. The spaces were well lit, clean and informative, with just the right amount of showmanship. Great job!

We stopped briefly, spent an hour and a half. Not nearly enough time to see all that they have here. GREAT planes, I love how they have them all worked in there. Hanging from the ceiling. They are saving as many as they can. And, thank you for that! If you are into this type of thing, I think you will be thrilled with the history here. If your not into this type of thing, I still think you would be entertained. And its FREE! Take a minute to explore. But really take more like a few hours. :-)
This is a great museum if you are interested in the history of war planes and the roles they played.

Several large hangars with military aircraft hanging from the ceiling or snuggled up next to each other. Aircraft from the very beginning of aerial warfare right on up to some of the current models flying. Outside, there are rows of larger transports, bombers, refueling aircraft, and the venerable B-52. Blackbird. B-1 bombers. Helicopters from the Mash era to the present. Then there are the guys inside (volunteers) who will bend your ear for as long as you will let them. An aviation buffs dream!

places_url_reviews_title: Wonderful museum for the whole family - and free!
places_url_reviews_comment:
Saw from the highway and decided to stop to check it out. Unfortunately it was near closing time so were only able to visit for less than hour. But it was enough to encourage us to come back.
The museum offers a great collection of aircraft and the volunteers are ready to offer tons of information.
Definitely recommended. Do not miss it.
Plan to spend two - three hours walking around both inside and out. Many amazing aircraft on display. And the best part is that it is free.
We spent 3 hours walking around looking at everything. It’s a FREE museum full of so much information! The gift shop was fun. Lots of little trinkets and shirts and everything reasonably priced.

places_url_reviews_title: A local gem not to be missed
places_url_reviews_comment: I love this place! Being former USAF myself, I have great pride in my branch of service. The museum is filled with history and a great collection of aircraft and support equipment. Be sure to see the movie and also talk to the volunteers. Most are retired service members who are very proud of their service and have a wealth of first-hand knowledge to share. Great to see younger generations involved as well to keep this history alive! It's free to visit, too!
I love how much you can learn here. My two young children were not that into it, except loved running around the big planes outside. I enjoyed how much there was to see and learn about.

places_url_reviews_title: Interesting for me and my grandkids.
places_url_reviews_comment: Everyone was friendly, accommodating and knowledgeable. You will find something of interest whether you have been looking and learn about airplanes your whole life you just have a passing interest. It is amazing how many exhibits they have. Airplanes, mostly the real thing, from Kiddy Hawk. If you have the chance, don't miss this one!!!

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to walk through history
places_url_reviews_comment: This is one of the finest care museums I have it in two. The displays and the quality of the aircraft is amazing. They even have a SR-71 blackbird on display.The outside display is also very impressive with some rare and his stork aircraft on display outside. Be ready to spend several hours here, there is so much to see and do and experience.

My husband and I are both from military families and are both interested in history. We thoroughly enjoyed seeing and reading about all of the aircraft and munitions from the Wright brothers era to recently retired military aircraft. The museum is well maintained and just wonderful! I highly recommend visiting.

places_url_reviews_title: Visited Hill A.F. museum with some out of town friends
places_url_reviews_comment: We enjoyed walking through the indoor museum as well as through the outdoor exhibits. The indoor museum and many planes on exhibit with good descriptions below. The staff was welcoming and were gracious in answering our questions and showing us some of the individual planes.

places_url_reviews_title: Tons of Cool Aircraft, and Cooler Stories
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum has a relatively large collection of military aircraft that spans most of the history of the U.S. Airforce. There is an outdoor and two indoor collections, and all are well-maintained, with well-designed displays and placards giving the history and information about each aircraft displayed. Admission is free, which is pretty remarkable,and kids really enjoy being able to get up close and personal with the aircraft. The only down side is that there are no planes in which you can tour or see the inside. The museum also provides some great stories, with its "Utah Aviation Hall of Fame" exhibit, and the USAF in Vietnam exhibit, which includes a section on prisoners of war and USAF (Vietnam) Medal of Honor recipients. If you have any interest at all in military aviation - or think you might possibly have an interest - this museum is well worth the visit.

If you like military aircraft, you will like this museum. They have many types of aircraft from early aviation to present. I was there for almost 3 hours. The volunteers are very cordial and informative. The museum is free but they appreciate donations. Get close to the aircraft of the past and present. Great place to visit.

If you have any interest in the vast number of airplanes not only the air force have used this is the place for you! There are so many things to see and a ton to learn fro airplanes to helicopters to the history of American wars. This is a free museum which in education.

They have some cool stuff. Plenty of vintage Air Force jets. An SR71. Many older planes as well from WWII. It was presented well in the first hangar. In the second hangar the aircraft were simply on display with nothing to give it context.
Excellent place to learn about the history of the USAF, Hill AFB and the great service men and women who have defended the USA.
This is a fantastic museum! The aircraft on display indoor AND outdoor are SUPERB! The staff is extremely knowledgeable and VERY FRIENDLY. Was able to recreate a photo from my USAF days. NICE!

We ended up visiting this museum as a last-minute decision and didn't know much about it beforehand. Oh my goodness--it was so much more interesting and huge than we were expecting it to be! Incredible number of vintage and modern military aircraft, all grouped by eras and the wars in which they were flown. The accompanying signs and displays were informative and really brought the history alive. We were so glad we stopped. And it was free to boot!

The planes are authentic. Its emotional when she see how the planes were constructed from and the materials used., ie canvas cloth, wires. An educational resource are the volunteers who answer questions or give additional commentary about how wars were fought. There is nostalgia but its also sobering to realize how war can start.

I went there because I love airplanes and in training to get my license so of course, I have to visit. It's so much bigger than other air museums I've visited in California (Santa Monica and Orange County).
Great information and history, lots to learn.

Not sure why more people don’t note this is free in their title!
It’s a huge display of military aircraft and some really interesting displays on both the craft and the people that fought in the US military during WW1, WW2, the Korean and Vietnamese Wars. I learned a few things that I am surprised there hasn’t been movies made about, like the women that flew for the Air Force in WW2 (the WASPs).
You could easily spend hours here if you have the time. There’s a small gift shop but no cafe.
The volunteer staff are lovely and keen to share their knowledge.
Take a camera!
Took my son here as he is obsessed with the military and history. We didn't allow enough time to fully appreciate everything they had here! Very educational and fun.
I love jets and this is a great place to see them up close. You also learn some history as you go. It's awesome to see an SR-71 inside
Incredible displays. NICE experience. I will be going again as there is so much to see. Took my 88 year old Dad. He wants to come back.
Lots to see - educational! Planes everywhere plus uniforms and other memorabilia. A wonderful tribute to our military and our wonderful flying machines.

This museum may be visited any time of the year, with indoor and outdoor displays.
Indoor displays include child-friendly activities. Outdoor displays allow visitors to get up close and personal with aircraft.

Hugh display of plane and other items inside two large buildings and a nice display of planes outside. Lots of data one can read by the planes and displays. FREE to get into, one can leave a donation. This was wonderful.
A fun place to take kids and grandkids to see airplanes and learn about aviation. Also fun for veterans to reminisce.
I would go back again ! The people were nice and very helpful. The planes and collections are amazing inside and out . The cost is on donation but I would even pay a fee well worth stopping.

I'm from Pensacola, which means I was judging this place against the Naval Aviation Museum. It holds up. This museum is the result of countless hours of restoration - I can't even imagine. It goes on and on, and when you walk around the outdoor exhibit, you get to see real live jets flying from the base. The gift shop is a great place to find gifts for all the kids in your life you never know what to get. I saw toddlers and senior citizens having fun here, so bring the whole family.

places_url_reviews_title: Not a Fly by and miss but a Must stop visit.
places_url_reviews_comment: This was one of the best museums we have stopped at on a military base. It is deceiving in size and has an unbelievable collection. Has volunteers working it and we had a couple of them that were there when it happened and really explained some of the history as they remember it. We took a lot longer then we thought we would as it was that good and so much. We will stop again as I know we missed absorbing some of ALL the information they have. I will recommend this stop to anyone that will be in the area to plan to take some time too see this. Cost is donation but is so good it would be worth a fee.
If you love history, come visit this museum! Well done, beautiful displays. Plenty to see both inside and outside. Quite a large variety of aircraft for a relatively small air museum.

places_url_reviews_title: Great FREE (donations welcome :) museum; awesome jets, ACE learning center for kids
places_url_reviews_comment: I've loved this museum since I was young. SR-71, F-16, A-10, lots of vintage aircraft. Retired/veterans are great hosts.

places_url_reviews_title: Great FREE museum for both young and old
places_url_reviews_comment: It doesn't matter if you are a kid, a teen, a parent, or a grandparent; this museum has something for everyone, and best of all--it is free to visit. Hundreds of historical airplanes for everyone to enjoy. A special note: many people don't know that there is a second building as big as the first directly behind the main museum. It has an old Airforce One and many other planes. Don't miss it. Once you have walked through both buildings take the time to enjoy all the planes out front. Truly a great place to visit. They have a gift shop that every kid will love to visit.

places_url_reviews_title: Can't miss this one if you are in the area
places_url_reviews_comment: The place will surprise everybody for being bigger than it looks and because has many different things to see. It is very close from my home, and I always take friends who come to visit. None of them have been ever disappointed.
We went to this museum with our Cub Scout Pack. The boys LOVED it. There was sooooo much to see! We didn't even have enough time to see all that we wanted to. Would be fun to return again!
Loved looking at the the warplanes, and it's either free or really cheap to get in. Do this one - well worth the time and $$

places_url_reviews_title: A must-see for any history or aviation fans!
places_url_reviews_comment: My husband and I were very glad that we chose to visit this museum! The number of airplanes is amazing! I really liked the mock-up of prisoner quarters at the "Hanoi Hilton" . The first-hand descriptions written by prisoners and multiple pictures were so interesting. Plan to spend a couple of hours here! Also no cost for parking or entry is a plus!

places_url_reviews_title: A definite for any airplane enthusiast
places_url_reviews_comment: If you love airplanes like I and are in the area, I would go to this Museum. There is no charge for admission and there is like 5 Acres of facilities full of airplanes and displays.

places_url_reviews_title: A Great Aviation Museum and it is all FREE!.
places_url_reviews_comment: Many times I have driven past here on the I-15 and we finally decide too stop in. This facility is top notch. The buildings are provided by the USAF and most staffing is provided by retired airmen. The hardware has been restored and several of the planes have a connection to Utah flyers and Hill AFB. Two hangers house many planes from the Wright Flyer replica to the SR71 Blackbird. Posters do a good job of describing the displays and give some of the historic events that these planes were involved in. Talking to some of these volunteers brings back memories of my time in the Royal Canadian Air Force (RCAF). I flew as a passenger is a few of these planes and seen many of them on radar screens. Exiting the buildings there is a static display of several of the larger planes including a B1B, B52 and a C119 Flying Boxcar which I had flew in back in 1963. All of this is free but you will be inspired to make a donation before leaving. Great!

This is such an amazing place.
You can see the classical aircraft from WW2, Corean and Vietnan wars and learn a lot of hystory.
Congratulations to the volunteer crew that maintain this place.
This a place you cannot miss!
Regards

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to visit with the young ones or oldies
places_url_reviews_comment: Great place to visit and look at the static aircraft close up. Even better when they have the airshow.
A historical visit viewing Air Force aircrafts of then and now. Very interesting and eduational descriptions of each aircraft on display.

a Little gem of the city. A must travel to item if you make it to Ogden. So many cool planes and jets to see in a static setting. The staff great and telling you all about the planes if you ask.
Kids would love this place since it has some really great planes on static.
P-51s P40, SR-71 some cool choppers.

My husband is an airplane fanatic, so this was a definite stop on our travels. It is very large with informative descriptions on the airplanes and other displays. There were no interactive activities for kids today, but both my oldest and youngest enjoyed it too. We stayed and explored for just over n hour. My husband really enjoyed all the older aircraft on display.
My daughter loved it, great place if interested in war history. Had hands on activities for kids. That was a plus

This museum is a great place to take the family to. So much to see. Planes outside and inside. Sometimes they have classss for the kids in their education rooms. There is a scavenger hunt you can print off for the older kids and adults. The volunteers are great if you have any questions. There is a gift shop if you want the kiddos to pick something out at the end. Bring a picnic lunch and sit on the tables provided outside. And take lots of pictures.
We love visiting this museum, is free and has a lot of history with their planes and uniforms. The kids enjoy every time we visit it.
Stop over on our way to antolope Island. Unfortunately they closed on Sunday. Just catch a glimpse of the jets outside the fence

places_url_reviews_title: Will bring tears to your eyes
places_url_reviews_comment: Free admission to one of the best air museums in the nation. The Vietnam War display will bring years to your eyes. Every plane is represented from WW2 through Vietnam and beyond. Takes about two hours when reading about the planes and how they served America. Well worth your time.

places_url_reviews_title: Military aviation history at its best
places_url_reviews_comment: If you want to find out what makes America the best country in the world you have to see this museum. It makes you proud to be and American. Everything in the museum is wonderful from the exhibits to the volunteers to the visual presentations. As someone who has visited the Air Force Museum in Dayton, Ohio I would rate this one right up there with the best.

Excellent variety of military aircraft. Aircraft both inside and outside all easily accessible. Absolutely family friendly. Definitely worth seeing if you have the slightest interest in the United States military and seeing aircraft that span generations.
We were very impressed at this free museum! Very interesting for us and the kids. Thanks for offering this history.

this is a must visit location every time I come to ogden to visit relatives. as an air force veteran I am able to see aircraft of my past especially the b-52 stratofortress of which I was a mechanic on. the exhibits are always changing and my trip to ogden is not complete without a stop to the museum.
This is a great place for kids and adults to learn more abut aviation history and several of the ward and conflicts.

Wish we had more time there but only had one and half hours until closing. Would have liked an air craft that my young nephews could have sat in the cockpit. Building quite warm this time of year no air conditioning.

places_url_reviews_title: Amazing, more than I had hoped for.
places_url_reviews_comment: Really cool museum! Our favorite part was walking among these incredible planes and learning the history and some personal stories behind them. I was shocked to see that there were hangers full of different aircrafts inside as well as the ones visible outside! We went on a HOT day and didn't spend as much time outside as we would have otherwise. If you are into planes or history at all this is a wonderful FREE place to drop by. Plan at least an hour or two.

places_url_reviews_title: Great way to spend an afternoon.
places_url_reviews_comment: We took teenagers and toddlers and everyone had a good time. There are so many planes! They even had a coloring station set up for the little ones.

We decided to surprise the kids with this stop on our Road Trip, and they loved, it! Our 9 year old loved reading all about the planes, and what they did and when they were active. It was a great fun history lesson, was so neat to stand next to them and just see the sheer size of some of these planes!! We wished that you were able to see what they looked like inside, that would have made it even better!! But honestly stop here!! It is free, but they have donation boxes and those fun coin donation (our boys love to send as many coins as they can spinning down them) things inside.

places_url_reviews_title: A trip through flight time machine
places_url_reviews_comment: any visitor coming this way, and local, should make this a trip for family and friends. Get to know your Air Force heritage and learn some things you definitely did not know
We really enjoyed the the museum and the people were great.A lot of old planes and the history behind them.

places_url_reviews_title: Wow, and all this is free!
places_url_reviews_comment: We didn't allow enough time to enjoy it all so we will go back. We skipped the movie as it was too technical for a general audience. Tip: The chapel is only open on Wednesday. Don't miss the adjoining buildings that are sort of tucked into the far right corner of the first building. Excellent collection!
Really interesting and unique place to have here in Utah. An exceptional display of historic and high-tech military aircraft

When children and grandchildren visit me here in Ogden, I have several places I like to take them. This is one of them. They have two large connected warehouses full of aircraft of all type. They also had many larger planes outside the museum. Grandchildren seem to love planes, trains and dinosaurs. Here in Ogden we have a railroad museum, a dinosaur park, and the aerospace museum. Everyone in the family, from toddlers to grandparents enjoyed the experience of seeing the large variety of aircraft of all eras.

The Hill Aerospace Museum preserves and displays a collection of mainly ex US Air Force aircraft. There is a good variety of airplanes with some relatively rare survivors including the Douglas C-124 Globemaster transport of the early 1950s. Some planes are in large hangars, others are displayed in the open. Well worth visiting.
We are regulars to the airplane museum. Not only do they have planes but they have fun workshops for kids during the summer!
My kids loved getting up close to the aircraft. Be sure to sign in at the desk when you arrive so they can report the numbers and keep their funding.

Easy on and off from the highway, they have an outdoor area with most of the planes in great shape. Think it was the B-47 needs a little TLC but I imagine the sun beating down on these lovely warbirds takes a lot of refurbishment. Two indoor areas were cool in the 90+ degree outside heat. One was fighters and the other bombers among other planes, missiles, and Hill AFB info. Worth the stop, can spend 1-2 hours and it's free but remember to donate!

I have been to a number of aviation museums and this one rates right up there with the top ones. Great static displays of aircraft covering the history of military aviation. Most of the planes have been meticulously restored and are in fantastic condition. First time I have seen a B1 Bomber in a museum. The best thing...free admission!

places_url_reviews_title: One of the best aviation museums anywhere.
places_url_reviews_comment:
Been here a few times. Always new exhibits and sometimes older airmen sharing real life experiences.
A few rare planes like the SR-71 and B-1 bomber.
A nice place to visit. Interesting but not something we will visit again real soon. The outside planes are great and it is all free.

Took my 7 year old Grandson to check out the Museum. Needless to say we both had a blast. Lots of different type of planes both inside and outside the Museum. There are retired airmen that Volunteer and are filled with fun facts and loads of information. We enjoyed ourselves and would go again.

This is a very well laid out display of acft both inside and outside, plus other displays of gear and equiptment, have some very interesting acft on display you will enjoy the time you spend there, the museum is outside the military base so you don't have to worry about ID cards to gain access to museum
Small but impressive displays. Great way to spend an afternoon for all ages. An invaluable history lesson for children.

We took a group of 10 year old girls to this museum and had a great time. They were so intrigued by the airplanes/jets. I was actually quite surprised at their long held interest in everything to see. It was bitter cold when we went. I would suggest a warmer day so the airplanes outside can be enjoyed longer.
Great aerospace type museum, the kids will love it, free to access, nice plane display, good visuals throughout, family friendly stop.

From the Interstate the Hill Aerospace Museum looks like just a few assorted planes sitting in the open. But if you stop in you'll be treated to a terrific display of military aircraft spread over a large outdoor exhibit and two enclosed galleries. An aerospace museum on an Air Force base is a formula for success and the Hill museum does not disappoint. Outside you can walk around a collection of mostly larger planes that includes many of the usual suspects as well as some lesser known models, such as the C-119 Flying Boxcar and the Bomarc missile; maybe the most elegantly designed weapon of the Cold War era and rarely seen at museums. The two large enclosed galleries start with a couple of early aviation replicas then move you directly to WWII, Korea, Vietnam, and a variety of Cold War era planes. Except for a few informational panels WWI is not represented. Don't expect to see other allies represented here. This is almost exclusively a history of U.S. military aviation with just a couple of foreign aircraft thrown in. In addition to the planes, a variety of other artifacts are salted throughout the exhibits with nice displays and good historical text. The Hill museum does a really nice job of personalizing the experience by tying some of the aircraft to notable Utah aviators. A staff of friendly, talkative, and knowledgeable volunteers will gladly answer your questions or share their stories. While not on par with the National Museum of the USAF in Dayton, this is one of, if not the best, pure military air museum west of the Mississippi. I know aviation museums aren't for everyone, but if you're into planes, or military history in general; this is worth a visit. Little boys will love it. By the way, admission is FREE.

Got there late and had to hurry but it was very very interesting. Loved by all 4 of us.
The planes were awesome and the staff knowledgeable. Lots and lots to see go early.
we asked one of the Volunteers to help us, he was willing to give us a guided tour, he did a fabulous job. Detailed stories and lots of extras

places_url_reviews_title: Great museum right off the Interstate
places_url_reviews_comment: I stopped here in June 2016 on the way back from a cross country trip. This is an incredible air museum - and it's free! There are a lot of aircraft on display outdoors and some on the inside too. Very easy access from I-15. This is definitely worth a stop if you like aviation history and military aircraft

places_url_reviews_title: They may be grounded, but they are still great.
places_url_reviews_comment: It is actually quite amazing the amount and array of aircraft they are able to fit in such a small space. One is able to get an amazing education while spending most of the time inside a climate controlled building. They have volunteers there to help answer any questions. The exhibit is great for all ages.

Worth the trip. Great history. Great volunteers. Amazing exhibits.
Cool gift dhop. Free entry (leave a donation)

This museum is an easy detour while in or on your way through the Salt Lake City area. It's an amazing collection, from the beginnings of flight but with an emphasis on WW II, Vietnam, and the Cold War. The veterans who volunteer there are each a font of information and their love of airplanes and the Air Force is palpable.
Wow, this is top notch. I have been to both NASA museums in Washington and the Naval museum in Florida. Hill's museum out does them all. By far more planes and a much closer view of everything.

places_url_reviews_title: Worth a stop and a donation
places_url_reviews_comment: We have stopped here several times in the past but haven't been in the last several years of so - Wow, what an improvement, these people are to be commended for doing a wonderful honor to the aircraft on exhibit. Some of these are rare and difficult to find in other places short of the Smithsonian or Wright-Patterson. Among the WWII aircraft on display are a B 25 Mitchell , Republic P 47 thunderbolt (aka jug), Consolidated B 24 Liberator, and Lockheed P-38 lightning, and a B 29 superfortress, - newer aircraft include a Convair F 106 Delta Dart, a Lockheed F 104 Starfighter, Boeing B 47 Stratojet, (wish they had a B58 hustler), Lockheed-Martin SR 71 Blackbird, Boeing B 1 Lancer and a Douglas C 124 Globemaster. the only complaint (and it's minor) is that despite being housed in two buildings and outside static displays they are somewhat crowded inside. Perhaps the best thing about it is that as you head north on interstate 1 - 15 it's an easy off and on. Take some time to enjoy this great museum, it used to be little but it's growing all the time.

I have taken my grandkids and other family members here. It is a surprising large air museum with numerous buildings chocked full of aircraft and aviation memoribelia. If you love jets and planes, this is the place for you!!!

places_url_reviews_title: Great fighter jets and airplanes of all shapes and sizes.
places_url_reviews_comment:
The best was the SR71 Blackbird but it was fun to see all kinds and sizes of planes and jets.
It is free to the public and open until 4pm.

places_url_reviews_title: A great place to see aircraft of all ages
places_url_reviews_comment: I've been here a few times and enjoyed each visit. There is a mix of older and newer aircraft. Hill AFB is named after the AAF test pilot at Wright Patterson AFB who crashed the Boeing B-17 prototype.
Really fun place to see aircraft that you would never be able to see otherwise. Little ones were interested for most of the time, but I was interested for all of it!

This is a great historical museum. The airplanes are all in such great condition, and the photos and stories of our veterans is wonderful! And there is usually some one on staff to answer any questions. My 5 year old grandson loves it!

Was meeting friends from Idaho for a long weekend and saw a billboard advertising the museum. We spent about 3 hours and certainly glad we did. The inventory of the museum is quite extensive for no larger that's it is. The SR-71 was the highlight for me although there are several different types of planes on site. They have Cargo, Fighters, Recon, experimental, you can see them here. The ancillary displays are very informative and detailed. I would recommend this for anyone whether or not you are a fan of flight. Oh, and did I say it's free? Okay, it's free to park AND admission!! Right off I-15 so easy to get to.

places_url_reviews_title: Exceptional collection of classic warbirds and more
places_url_reviews_comment: I make it a point as I travel to stop and see various aircraft museums. Even though I live near the HAFB Museum, I make repeat visits here five to six times a year, it is that good. Not only the aircraft, but uniform and flight suit collection, as well as exceptional static displays of the aircraft as they would have been seen ready to fly in their prime. My highest recommendations to the Hill Aerospace Museum. A must see for aviation fans.
Lots of WWII planes and later ones. A convenient location if you are staying in Salt Lake City. Will go back if I am in the area.
Great place for Air Force history! So many different aircrafts from World War I to the present. And it was free.

I love, love, LOVE this place! It is a MUST SEE for kids, adults and aviation enthusiasts. Two HUGE hangers packed FULL of airplanes of all eras. My favorite is, of course, the SR-71. Simply awesome. Then there is an outside walk to see even more HUGE airplanes. There are former pilots that can show you around or share a few stories. There are activity rooms for kids with flight simulation and other fun things. Great gift shop. You could easily spend hours there. Plan a whole day to enjoy with amazing place.
This is a very large and free attraction to see many planes and helicopters and stories of the US Air Force. It was raining so we couldn't see the outdoor planes (we didn't have an umbrella)
This was a great experience. Lots to see and very well organized. Outside and inside items on display and a really nice gift shop.

places_url_reviews_title: Great Way to Experience Our Country's Flight History
places_url_reviews_comment: My coworkers and I were in town for work, and decided to drop in to take a look. This is truly a hidden gem of a museum that is tucked away in a small town of just over 60,000. You start with a replica of the Wright Brothers' first planes and progress through our country's aviation history. I am glad we stopped by. While we didn't get a chance to try out the flight simulator, we throughly enjoyed our time at the museum. I will surely be paying another visit to the museum with my kids.

DO NOT EVEN THINK of leaving the Roy/Ogden area without stopping in to see this huge museum. I am not into aerospace, but have been here 3 times with children and teenagers and will go again. Everyone will enjoy it. Many hands on displays in and outside. You can go inside some of the aircraft and always lots of retired airmen waiting to assist you with any questions. You can't help but feel patriotic as you spend a couple hours here.

places_url_reviews_title: Best military museum west of the Mississippi
places_url_reviews_comment: Excellent collection of Warplanes and helicopters located on Hill Air Force Base. Very nice Vietnam display to include lots of statistics and photos. Excellent POW display. One of the few places in the world you can stand next to a B-29 bomber or an SR 71. Admission is free, donations are accepted. Good for kids or seniors. Great attraction.
Tons of great aircraft on the tarmac and a wonderful indoor museum. They have some real gems, including beautiful SR-72 Blackbird. Also a great gift shop.
