places_url_reviews_title: Surreal, but an excellent history lesson
places_url_reviews_comment:
I love aviation, but I hate war. This excellent museum hits both extremes. Viewing all these amazing planes in an almost ideal setting (more on that later), is a testimony to the amazing inventors, engineers, fabricators, and of course, pilots. Learning about airplanes as weapons (e.g., gunnery capable of thousands of rounds per minute), battle details (excellent timeline of Korean "conflict") and collateral damage (a history of the Hanoi Hilton) was a very very harsh history lesson. And then there are the B bombers in the outdoor boneyard, each capable of delivering incalculable payloads. All in all, an amazing experience, although hardly a sugar-coated inducement to enlist.
My only wish was that there was better viewing access to at least some planes. There are almost no elevated up-close viewing platforms, and none could be entered. I would loved to be able to sit on the flight deck, touch the controls and let my imagination take over.

Took the monkeys AKA grand kids to visit this museum on Presidents day, though it was windy out they had a nice time looking at all the old military planes and reading about them. The admission is free but they do accept donations to help with the upkeep of the museum. They have a small gift shop where all the proceeds go back to the museum. In the summer they have a car show there and they open up and let you go inside some of the planes. Totally worth going.
Great place to take the kids, and family or friends visiting to see airplanes. There are some old and some new. Good exhibitions too. And it is free.

This is the finest air museum next to Wright/Patterson. The displays are numerous and first class. Early planes all the way up to the latest jets. The fighter display is really nice. They also have the SR71 Blackbird. Admission is free with a few volunteers explaining the planes and operations. They have both indoor and out door displays. Cold or rainy days you can stay inside, but I would recommend seeing all that is on display. Located adjacent to Hill Air Force Base you can also watch the new F35's come and go.

Been here as a kid now when we had friends up we took them and our young boys to it. Lots of fun planes to see. Some more modern and some that are old. Totally worth the visit. Best part is admission is free. They do have a place where you can donate to help with upkeep but admission is free :)
The Aerospace Museum is great for kids, families or as a date night. It has a large variety of planes to look at and is ran really well. It's always a great experience.

3rd Best? yup the only ones to top this are the Smithsonian in DC and Wright Patterson AFB. My family loves planes and we have several generations of AF pilots in our family who have flown from Korea through the Gulf war. We stop at every plane museum or display we find. The facility is exceptional with everything very clean, the Aircraft are meticulously restored or maintained by expert volunteer technicians with plenty of folks around to answer any question you may have. This is worth the stop.

places_url_reviews_title: Great Military Museum and its FREE!
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum has both indoor and outside exhibits. From the one era to another, Large and small. If you love planes or military history this is the place. Everything from planes, bombs and uniforms worn by our brave men and women of our Military forces. The museum is free but you can drop a donation in the donation box on your way in or out. There is also a small pioneer museum next door you can check out. Great group tour for school or summer programs.

This place is awesome!! I went here with my brother to kill about an hour and we ended up staying for 4 hours. This place has so many cool things to see and a lot of history to read about. The volunteer staff was incredibly knowledgeable and very friendly. All you have to do is just ask them anything and they are willing to explain anything and everything about what's in the museum. They also have a nice gift shop with really cool toys and souvenirs for everyone.
This place is a must see.
Been here many times. One of the best aerospace museums. Large and varied assortment. But continuously being expanded and upgraded.

places_url_reviews_title: Great museum for adult and kids!
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a great free museum for anyone who likes history, airplanes, or military. Great place to stop if you have little or lots of time! Volunteers are knowledgeable and share great stories. It's one our families favorites.

This museum is full of aircraft and history both inside the building and out. My family got to my dad swearing in my brother into the Air Force on the backdrop of the American Flag and jets. Then my dad told his stories of the flying helicopters for the Air Force both in the states and in Asia. We gathered a little crowd as he regaled us with his exploits.
It was a special day for us and we really enjoyed the museum and the men and women who help run it for FREE. Yup, this awesome museum is FREE. (Of course, they do take donations).
This is worth a couple of hours of exploring.

I love going here is best history lesson children could ever learn. I love the history behind it. Taking small children to this Museum they learn more here at this museum than they do in history class.
Took my Grand children to see the planes. It was very interesting to see all the planes and learn of the history behind them.

We planned part of our Christmas vacation around a visit to the Hill Aerospace Museum. We are so glad that we did. The displays were amazing! My kids, ages 7-15, were all engaged with the planes, helicopters, and stories for almost 2 hours. I loved reading about the Doolittle Raiders and seeing the replica of the aircraft carrier. It was a bit chilly so we did not get to spend as much time with the displays outside as we wanted. We had the opportunity to visit with two Vietnam Veterans volunteering there. They were so happy to visit with us about flying helicopters and differences between the choppers and planes. We will be back next time we are through Ogden.

I've been here many times, but this was the first trip with my grandson. Seeing it through his eyes was refreshing. I have my favorites planes to ogle and dream of flying, and he added his own delight to others. There are enough planes and aviation-related items to marvel at for several visits. Not everything is in pristine shape, such as the forlorn little O-2 FAC aircraft wedged in as an afterthought in the Fighter Hangar. One thing they need is a snack bar or mini-cafe. People would spend more time there if they didn't get hungry or thirsty.

This museum is worth going to check out and see all the awesome planes and copters. It's a free museum but donations are appreciated. I've been here 4 times and have enjoyed every visit. There's lots of displays to check out so plan on at least 4 hours there.

places_url_reviews_title: Get there early enough to see everything
places_url_reviews_comment:
The museum is a little sparse on 'early' aviation, focusing on WW2 to the current day. That being said there are some interesting possibly unique exhibits, such as the reverse engineered V1 flying bomb in American markings, and the only SR71 "C" model ever built.
The outdoor exhibits are also quite interesting- ranging from twin engine propeller planes to a massive B52

The Hill Aerospace Museum is a fascinating travel through aviation and the planes used in US conflicts. All planes on display are full size with docents to explain what you are seeing and the history behind the planes. There is an interactive section for children and their parents to make rockets that staff will later launch. There is coloring pages for the younger children and other activities. Depending on the season your are visiting there is also planes that are available to go in side. Before visiting check out their website for visiting times and activitiesss.

Fun and a must go to! Kids have a great time and there is so much to look at. Can even just be an hour or two there and it's a great time. Not to crowded and it's very spacious inside the museum. Will go here again gladly.

Yeay, you likely only gave yourself a few hours for this museum—you are going to run long, plan on half a day. Such a cool place, and not jsut all the planes and displays, the volinteers and staff are super cool.

Visited this museum for the first time over Thanksgiving 2016. Very large facility with many planes representing the wars and missions over time. Every airplane has a plaque identifying what you are looking at and tells a brief history of its use. Very clean facility inside and out. The interactive exhibits were very interesting as well. The employees were very friendly and willingly answered all our questions. Great attraction to visit and best of all, IT'S FREE!!!

We visited the Hill Aerospace Museum because of my families connection to the Air Force. However, this is a very interesting museum for anyone interested in planes and history. There are many planes to look at both inside (2 hangars) and out along with many artifacts. They have done an excellent job in the informational displays and video boards. Highly recommend visiting. It is about a half hour away from Salt Lake City. We arrived about 11am, and finished around 2pm, but if we had watched the movie and listened to every video board we could have easily been there until between 3pm and 4pm.

We always take our out of town guests to visit this museum. There are some amazing attractions, both inside and out. Plan on spending at least an hour if you're interested in learning a lot! Great for the kids, too.

Every time we take our family to this museum, we find a new and fun experience! They have several interactive exhibits, and hangers full of airplanes, helicopters, and several learning rooms. Make sure you try the flight simulator. Bring some extra money and make a donation to restoring planes, or find some treasures in the gift shop that has something for everyone. Enjoy
My plane-obsessed teenager had a great time seeing all the planes. Even the rest of us who are not so obsessed had a good time walking around and seeing the historic exhibits.

Just off the interstate I-15, easily found. Plenty of parking. A few outside aircraft, the large ones (B52). But the inside is amazing. First hangar has older aircraft and second has newer jet fighters. Outstanding display. Nice gift shop, but no snack bar. Friendly folks and knowledgeable tour guides. Plan on a couple hours, unless you love planes, then probably more. Located at Hill AFB, you might catch some Air Force planes flying around also.

places_url_reviews_title: Great samples of avionic throughout military history.
places_url_reviews_comment: I like this museum because it has such the variety of aircraft through time. You can get up close and personal with most of the aircraft. They even have an SR71 Blackbird there. Also, there is an air show every June that features the Thunderbirds, among other performers. There is also a small gift shop to get a memento on your way out. I got my key chain that says "remove before flight".
Great displays of aircraft, indoor and out. If you love airplanes and history, you'll have a great visit here.

This place can make you proud to be a American, and fullfill your dreams of Flight... One fine place..... Great displays of every era of Flight, with real full displays of each of the aircraft of that era. Great place for the entire family.... Women ever love to fly too.....
This is a great museum for the aerospace enthusiast. Good history and collection of aircraft and memorabilia.

We usually hit this site anytime we have guest in town. It has many types of planes and other things relating to the Aerospace Industry. There is also a lot of information given as well. We have never had any of our guest regret our taking them there.
Excellent place to spend an afternoon an aviation museum with a lot of displays and planes and don't miss the SR 71 Blackbird. Indoors and out and right off the freeway

places_url_reviews_title: A great place to about Airplanes
places_url_reviews_comment: I have been to the Museum twice in the last two years. They have added more planes. It is a very educational experience to spend two or three hours there. It is amazing to see these planes up close .

places_url_reviews_title: This museum is great my favorite is the SR-71 Blackbird.
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a huge museum so plan a for a lot of time. There is part indoor and some outdoor . This museum is free. It could take quite a few hours to see and learn. Very interesting and educational also cool. Not something you have to drag the kids to they will love it.

This is a nice stop for families and children. There is a lot of Air Force aviation displays dated over the decades. This attraction is free but they do accept donations to maintain and restore the planes. Displays are inside and outside. Nice stop for plane gurus.
My boys and I always have a great experience here. Fascinating displays from all major conflicts starting from the first world War on.

Free admission...but deposited a nice donation to help keep it going. What a neat and huge display of war planes, jets and helicopters! Two huge indoor museums and a large outdoor space with many more flying machines. Museum experience could be enhanced with headphone tour or live tour guides...It got old quick reading all of the data sheets for each plane or jet. Easy to get to & near Weber State in Ogden.
If you are in the area this museum would be worth your while. There are lots of helicopter, bombers, jets and great displays. Plan on taking at least two hours inside and out to see everything.
This air force museum is packed with aircraft. The ones outside are not in great shape but it is amazing to see how large they are.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the best air museums in the country!
places_url_reviews_comment: So much history to explore here! Lots of knowledgeable volunteers (many former/retired military). I did my Air Force retirement ceremony here last year...what an awesome place

places_url_reviews_title: Get up close to real fighters and bombers
places_url_reviews_comment: We visited this museum as a family and even my grumbly teens loved it. Being able to see real military planes up close and personal was incredible. The highlight is some of the planes they have indoors, particularly the SR 71 Blackbird. Awe inspiring!

places_url_reviews_title: Plane Nuts will love this place
places_url_reviews_comment: Really worth the stop! If you are an airplane nut then this will be worth the stop. Not only the static displayed planes but look at the small displays, they are so well done.

The Hill Aerospace museum has a lot to see and do inside. I went to an aerospace museum in Denver, it wasn't near as good as this one, and it cost more in Denver. There is quite a wide variety of planes, from many different eras and times. I went with my nieces and nephews and they loved seeing what the museum had to offer, and that was one of the most fun parts! It's also interesting for adults!

I have been to many air museums across the country. Most of them are quite interesting, but this one seems to be quite well done, with many unique displays and a volunteer staff of very knowledgeable retired gentlemen. A must see is the SR 71 Blackbird. And, to top it off, all of this is free admission.
If you are at all interested in planes and war history, this is a very good museum. And the best part, it is free.
We came upon this traveling from Salt Lake to Ogden.. Its free and has lots to see...old airplanes inside the museum and out. Very informative and fun..

Stopped at Hill AFB Museum to see their collection. No charge to enter. Planes are displayed both indoors and outdoors. Stats are given for each of the planes. Easy to spent 2 to 3 hours here.
If your in the area, this is worth a visit
Great place to see planes from ww2 and Vietnam. Two hangers full of airplanes plus about a dozen outside as well. Great for all ages!

places_url_reviews_title: Second only to the Smithsonian in Wash DC
places_url_reviews_comment: An excellent collection of AF aircraft that are expertly displayed. Several docents available for insights during holidays and most weekends. All this for no admission cost but they deserve any donations to preserve this gem

places_url_reviews_title: Excellent display of historic Aerospace Items
places_url_reviews_comment: Having some knowledge was helpful but seeing actual planes etc made it all come to life. Helps have a better understanding of the reality of progress that has been made over the years!

There are so many planes and so much information on them. It is definitely alot of fun!! There are also volunteers that are very helpful with sharing information about alot of the fights the planes were involved in.

Anyone who loves planes or history will enjoy this museum. It's great for all ages. I love looking at the old war planes. It's like going back in time. Veterns volunteer there and like telling you stories.
Have gone here twice on visits to Ogden Utah. Took a group of kids once and they loved it. If you have extra time then go here. Its free.

I've seen this museum many times but I'm glad I finally stopped. It is completely free and located outside the Hill AFB fence so anyone can go in. They have an outside airpark and then two different display hangars inside. It's primarily manned by volunteer retirees but they are full of great information and provide tours too. It's not a huge museum but it covers airplanes from the Wright Brothers up to the present. Great way to spend a couple of hours.

places_url_reviews_title: Wonderufl, educational and outstanding exhibit at Hill Air Force Base
places_url_reviews_comment: We were in town visiting family and since both are Air Force veterans they took us to this U.S. Air Force museum that is part of the United States Air Force Heritage Program. It was a wonderful place to spend a morning. The exhibits inside and the static displays outside are amazing and the volunteers who are usually veterans are ready to answer any questions you may have. It is so great seeing all the aircraft you might have only read about up close and walking through Air Force History in WWII, Korea, Vietnam and beyond. If you are in the Salt Lake City area I would highly recommend a visit to this museum.

Hill's museum has a great cross section of aircraft. Hill has been a logistic hub and is currently the home of the first operational F-35 wine. There are always interesting planes flying around and the museum has developed a great collection of warrior aircraft from WW2 to date. Indoor planes are great conditions and outdoor planes are classics if a little weathered.

Over the years, this is a consistently favorite place to visit! I am always pleased to see veterans on hand as docents as well as the cleanliness and quality of the exhibits! I wish they had done if the most modern jets abs missiles but this isn't wright Patterson and it is free to the public. This is such a wonderful local resource I highly recommend to all!

I was ant the museum for a friends promotion ceremony. It is a great venue for that.
The museum has some great displays to include an SR 71 and one of only 2 A7Fs in existence.
It really brings back some memories of the Close Air Support aircraft I've worked with. They have an old Observer Cub, O-2,OV-10, as well as an A-10 just to name a few of the dozens they have on display. I'll be going back today in order to spend more time checking out he displays.
It's a wonderful place. We come from Atlanta Georgia, for visitors our family. And taking advantage of the opportunity. To know about the big flying machine. All family so happy.

I haven't been here since I was a kid but I really enjoyed it. The building is bigger than it looks and there is aircraft inside and outside of the building. It's free and gives a good option to visit when you want a nice day out.
It's a fantastic museum with many vintage planes and exciting displays and videos, but they close too early. Doors shut at 430pm, no exceptions. Tough to go when you don't get off work until 5pm.

The Hill AFB base museum should not be missed by any family travelling Interstate 15. Kids and adults alike can wander through the decommissioned aircraft while F16, A10s and C20s take off and land on the runways on the Hill. It's an airshow every day!
As good as the museum in Seattle or DC for the price. Tons of airplanes from across the last 100 years. Kids had a blast being that close to some amazing machines.

We enjoyed our visit to the Hill Aerospace Museum. I tend to live in the present, and I am glad that others have the forethought to preserve the Past. Air Force and Aerospace history unfolds in front of you as you tour this museum. Exterior displays give you insight to the size and scope of some air machines. The inside exhibits are wonderfully managed and preserved. There is No Admission fee, this is a free attraction. Closed on Sundays. The facility is air conditioned and it felt great on a hot July day. The gift store is bright and a great place to purchase souvenirs.

places_url_reviews_title: Nice to visit if you like planes!!
places_url_reviews_comment: The Museum is really cool with a wide variety of planes. I like the big black spy plane from the cold war. Kids will love it specially if they like planes.

places_url_reviews_title: awesome museum for airplane buffs, nice add-on visit to Antelope Island for others
places_url_reviews_comment:
I visited this museum in the afternoon, after spending the morning at the Antelope Island State Park to visit the Great Salt Lake. I was staying at a hotel in downtown SLC. To go back to the city, I had to drive 15 minutes from the island to a town called Layton. From there, I would get on I-15 going south to SLC. Hill Museum is in Roy which is 5 minutes drive in the other direction on I-15 North.
I am not an airplane buff, but I still can appreciate the value of this place with its sheer size and the vast number of airplanes -- there are 2 hangars each with about 20+ airplanes, then an outdoor park with about another 20+ airplanes. I also really enjoyed the notes on the placards that explained the historical background associated with each airplane and the details of the wars those planes flew in. I spent about 2 hours there..
In short, if you have a special interest in military history or airplanes, then it's a must visit place. If you are just an average person, then it's a nice add-on excursion if you go to Antelope Island to visit the Great Salt Lake, which by the way is a must-visit if you like nature and the outdoors.

We went here with our 3 year old grandson, who loves planes... He really enjoyed running around from plane to plane, it was great to be able to get up close to so many old war planes, and it has lots of history here as well!

I've been here twice; once on a school trip and the other as part of my birthday with my mother. I'm honestly not that into planes, if I were; this place would be pretty awesome. There are lots of different kinds of fly in the sky things. There's also a kids room of sorts which I think is really cool and fun, and a gift shop. I got astronaut ice cream from the gift shop. It made me feel sorry for astronauts because its nowhere near as good as normal ice cream. Also, I should mention that this place is free. You don't have to pay to enter.

places_url_reviews_title: Best Air Force Museum I Have Seen
places_url_reviews_comment: The museum is located just outside the gate of Hill Air Force Base. As you go down the driveway to the museum you are surrounded by scores of planes from our military's past and present. Everything from B-52s to B-29s, tankers, helicopters, fighters, a B-1 Bomber and transport aircraft await your attention. The museum building itself houses more fighters and bombers, rescue aircraft, observation aircraft and helicopters. A Wright Flyer and WW1 Jenny are present. Everything is spotless. You can feel the history and courage of our Air Crews. If you are in Utah you cannot miss seeing this. Except for Wright Patterson in Ohio there is no better or larger collection of historical aircraft. My family loved this place. Amazingly, there is no charge to see all this. You can make a donation of you want, but no one will bother you if you do not choose to do so.

We only had an our for this museum so we were super rushed. We did t know what we were getting in to just a last minute, LETS DO IT adventure. You could spend HOURS here. Kids of all ages will enjoy this place. Fun and educational.

places_url_reviews_title: Can't beat the price of admission
places_url_reviews_comment: I might even pay to get in. But it's free! Lots to aircraft to see inside and out. Just wish it was open on Sun but, budget cuts took care of that.
Wonderful exhibits. Lots of beautiful planes and helicopters. A fantastic experience. I would recommend it to anyone with even a slight interest in planes.

Great place to visit if you are in the area to see all kinds of airplanes. The actual pilots are also available to talk about flying them so it is really neat to do. They also have inert bombs including nuclear ones and a SR-71 Blackbird on display. Great photo opportunities. Even if you are not into planes it is a MUST stop.

And yes, it is free, but they ask you to make a donation (which we did). Two big rooms plus a large field of planes. The fighter planes room is the crown jewel... Housed inside is F16s, Phantom IIs, helicopters and the best of all, the Lockheed SR71 Blackboard. Many WW2 fighters with the cool artwork also housed here.. Outside is the president's Airforce One and more war planes including a B1 stealth bomber. It's the best museum I've ever been to.

This place is a great way to spend an hour or four hours depending on your time. There are great stories and so many planes that you'll find yourself taking hours reading about them. The day we went they had a kids craft building glides at 10:30.

My kids loved everything about the place. Very well put together and best of all no cost. The only thing the kids would have loved was to be able to get in a plane but I'm sure that's just red tape they don't want to deal with.

places_url_reviews_title: Great family activity!! and It's FREE!!
places_url_reviews_comment:
This is a great family activity. It is important that we all realize that, "Freedom isn't Free".
I think all ages will love this activity.

More history than you can possibly absorb in a single afternoon, but well worth the trip, even if you only stop in for a quick visit. Absolutely free, including parking, and very easy to access off of I-15.
Sobering array of aircraft from all eras of aviation. The huge, supersonic SR-71 Blackbird spy plane, the fastest plane ever built, is an obvious highlight. If that's all you come for it's worth it but there's so much more. It's a great way to learn history without a textbook.

Yes, I said free. No admission charge, no parking fee. And you start seeing aircraft as soon as you turn onto the property - the outdoor display lines the road to the parking lot. The museum tells the story of military aviation in Utah and how it relates in particular to Hill AFB. It shares a freeway exit with the truck gate to Hill, so pay attention to directional signs. (Don't worry; if you arrive at the gate to Hill, they will politely turn you around rather than shoot you). They cram a remarkable number of large aircraft into two relatively small indoor halls. The really big planes (including a B-52) are located outside. While not as well interpreted (or funded, for that matter) as the Udvar-Hazy Center of the Smithsonian or the museum at Wright-Patterson AFB in Ohio, the volunteers are every bit as knowledgeable, informative, and helpful. This is well worth your time if you find yourself in the area. The museum is an easy 30-minute drive north from Salt Lake City or just minutes south from downtown Ogden.

The exhibits are great, the information is wonderful, and it's nice to be able to walk up and get so close to the plains. Admission is free but I always make sure to donate something to help keep it going. Make sure you visit both indoor galleries, look off the mezzanine in the first gallery, and tour all the planes outside. Great collection

This museum at Hill Air Force Base is just off the I-15 freeway. Easy to get to and easy to get back on the road. The first thing you notice is the large number of historic aircraft parked outside. It could take you an hour just to walk through and examine them in detail, and yes, you can walk up to them and touch. Unfortunately, you can't get inside them. I was surprised to see that since my last visit, they have added a B-52 and a B-1. Just the B-52 was a thrill to see and stare at!
Then enter the museum itself. The small foyer will not prepare you for the two large hangars full of aircraft. WW1, WW2, Korea, Viet Nam, and Gulf War planes are in there, along with more prosaic aircraft. You (and particularly your children) will love it. And will get sore feet from walking around. A theater constantly runs very enlightening movies about various aircraft. Even the gift shop is a joy to visit.
Oh, and it is FREE. They will gladly accept donations, and you will see that a donation will be given gladly. This collection is worth a large admission fee!

My son and husband were blown away. My three-year-old exclaimed constantly, "Wow, mommy look at that airplane!". We were amazed it was free admission. It's a wonderfully organized museum bursting with amazing airplanes and so much information.
If you love military planes you'll love this place. Several planes throughout aviation history from a replica of the Wright Bros. plane to an SR-71.
From the outside static display of he B-52 etc to the inside display from all eras to include Bi-planes to the Huey Chopper to the SR 7 this is a great museum. Be sure to have some time for this one.

places_url_reviews_title: Easily accessible collection of warplanes & stories about them
places_url_reviews_comment: Excellent collection of fighter planes, trainers, bombers, & cargo planes. Signs gave good summaries of why the airplane category was valued, Hill AFB's role with it, and how the plane on display was restored. AF veteran volunteers were very helpful. Excellent for families.

places_url_reviews_title: Tour the planes inside and outside the museum
places_url_reviews_comment:
You'll see everything from bi-plans to modern bomberstosurveilence craft.
Great place to take the kids.
A lot of historical notes on the planes inside the museum
This museum is great for all ages and it is free. My kids love going to this museum. There is a lot to see and learn about.
We visited this museum with family. There is a great outside exhibit and the inside museum. Wonderful displays, and it is very educational. WAY TO GO USAF!!!!

Packed with exhibits, and an excellent display of historic aircraft, this is worth the time to visit. Two large buildings, plus many large transport airplanes parked outside, it is just off the freeway and easy to access, free admission, and lots of parking.

We took my son here for his birthday and he loved it! There were tons of different planes to look at, and they also do tours. They even have a small gift shop as well. The planes that are too big to be inside the building are out front. Very fun to see and learn about some of our history.

What's not to like about an excellent museum which is FREE (donations appreciated)? The Hill AFB Museum is 30 acres with two major hanger areas and outside exhibits with over 90 aircraft and missiles, easily accessible off I-15 without having to enter restricted Hill AFB. Aircraft start in time with a Wright Brothers replica, mainly skip WWI, but have most of the famous fighters and bombers starting with WWII and progressing to the B1 Lancer and SR 71 Blackbird. For history buffs, there are plenty of plaques to read describing each aircraft, as well as videos and other displays of wartime history. You can spend a couple of quick hours or a full day.

My wife, daughter-in-law and four grandchildren visited the Hill Aerospace Museum and spent several hours taking in the amazing array of airplanes on display. I watched a great video of the P-51 Mustang being flown by the son of a WW2 pilot who had flown one in combat. Staff was friendly and helpful, great souvenir store complete with books about the aircraft and their deployment, all wheel chair accessible. Anyone interested in military aircraft large or small won't be disappointed. The history of the base is on display. Great visit.
My Grandpa was in the air force during the Vietnam war. He really enjoyed seeing all the equipment and told the kids lots of stories. The kids thought it was fun, they loved all the big airplanes!

I will come back to this museum because I just didn't have enough time to do it justice. The planes and jets are just amazing but I loved reading about the men who flew them. This is a great trip for young kids. It made me want to go home and read up on some aviation history.
We brought the entire family here for the afternoon. Tons of history, activities for the kids.....it was just awesome. Lots of planes and relics.

places_url_reviews_title: This place is awesome, especially for kids!
places_url_reviews_comment: There is a HUGE assortment of military aircraft here, including an SR71 Blackbird, and a scale model of the Wright Brothers plane. The staff is mostly retired Air Force personnel, which really adds to the uniqueness of the place. Many of them can tell you personal stories regarding particular aircraft they flew or serviced. There is a special wing dedicated just to Space flight. Admission is free and there is a donation box inside should you wish to contribute to keep the museum open. A great free trip to see cool planes and maybe even learn a thing or two.
This is a wonderful place to visit with the family. There are so many incredible airplanes here with unique and rich history, it's a great place to burn a few hours.

Hill AFB Museum is a 'must visit' if you are in or passing through the area. Huge collection of aircraft, missiles, bombs and other exhibits, great for families and seniors alike. You probably need a minimum of a couple of hours for a very quick walk around, but enthusiasts could easily spend the whole day here. Highlights: SR-71 Blackbird & many other cold war jets, interesting exhibits and no entrance charge. Very close to the Freeway about 25 miles north of SLC. Bonus was the F-35's circling and landing at the active AFB adjacent. I visited mid-May on a Thursday morning and it was very quiet there.

Spent half a day going round here before flying back to Houston, wished I'd know about it before as I could have stayed longer. They have a fantastic collection here. Some inside and some out, so you can go in all weather conditions. Entrance is free as well. Staff were very friendly and were eager to provide help and information if required. Great place to go to.
Great place to take the kids and adults too! lots of history and different types of aircraft. We were there at Easter and they had a great Easter egg hunt for all the kids.

We have gone to HABM several times. the volunteers are well informed and willing to provide extensive detail on the exhibits. The museum is well laid out and has lots of interest for the entire family, even young chidren.

I have been to a number of "air" museums. The Air and Space Museum in Washington DC and the Air Force Museum in Dayton, Ohio are better, but only because they have more stuff. I'm partial to this museum because one of the planes on display I actually flew in, heck I threw up in it. It's a great place to see old planes and it right off the freeway on Roy exit. It will keep the kids occupied and it's free.

I've visited this museum many times...great visit for families, history buffs, scouts, schools, etc. Excellent docents with lots of real stories & several hands-on activities for the kids. Open from 9am-4:30pm Mon-Sat, with some holidays closed. Best part is that admission is FREE! Plan on a couple hours to see everything...

This museum is on the Hill Air Force Base and is free. Very easy to find. Outdoor exhibits were all labeled and gave good, interesting facts about each one. Inside were more planes, an entire wall of Vietnam War info, model of the Hanoi Hilton, and more. There is so much to see and read about, you could easily spend all day here.

A great stop for 2-3 hours. Access is easy from I-15 at Exit 338. The address in this review does not come up on Garmin GPS. Parking easily accommodated our 5th wheel. We very much enjoyed the displays and the written info. The SR-71 video was the highlite. To get the whole benefit of the museum, would require multiple visits

I took my son here for his 4th birthday. He was in heaven. Two large hangars of airplanes and memorabilia and many more jets and planes outside. There are veteran volunteers to answer any questions and tell amazing stories. I'd like to go back so I can read and learn more without my excited boy wanting to move from display to display.

This is a free experience. We've been there several times with our kids and always enjoy our visits. Most of the displays are inside, which is nice in the winter. It is a smaller museum than many we've been to, but still has a great collection. They also have lectures, summer classes for elementary school aged kids, veteran pilots to talk to, movies, a hands on "play" area, and a gift shop. Pre-school aged children we saw did not seem to be enjoying themselves, so this may not be the best experience for younger children.

There is a large collection of military aircraft, and most of them are fully restored. There are other artifacts, such as uniforms and other flying equipment. I enjoyed just walking around and looking at the exhibits, as well as reading the information available. Great place for anyone into military history.

places_url_reviews_title: Make time to visit Hill Aerospace Museum!-Free Admission!
places_url_reviews_comment:
The outdoor display is great, but it is only a fraction of the aviation history preserved indoors!
We were very surprised that there was not an admission fee!
The displays are extremely well presented and gives a true appreciation of aviation history.
There are also a lot of volunteers throughout the buildings willing to give information about the displays.
This is a must-see if you are in Salt Lake City or surrounding towns!

places_url_reviews_title: American aviatin military history of past and present in one site!
places_url_reviews_comment:
I love this place as it is only 7 miles from my home and I consider myself an amateur military buff! The second you see this place, you know you are in for a treat! From the F4 Phantom to the Douglas C-124C Globemaster II which dominates the area and building, the planes represented here are well preserved and still bear original markings and have detailed plaques explaining their place in history.
My favorite plane is the B-29 Superfortress and its older sibling, the B-52. The B-29 on display here flew the weather reconnaissance mission over Japan in advance of the twin B-29s waiting over the Pacific ocean with their deadly and war-ending payloads of atomic bombs. Just to be able to touch this piece of American history is amazing. To know that this plane was so significant in ending the Pacific theatre is beyond phenomenal. And to some it may just be an old plane but I am a die hard fan,
There is a current F-16 Falcon on display along with Korean and Vietnam era flying machines in all their glory. Add in a few personal trainers and some ramjet missiles and other types of support equipment and you have a great place to visit.
The best part is that the outdoor exhibit is 100% FREE!! You can drive in, park, and start to wonder to your heart's content.
The museum is an equally attractive event and chronicles how the nearby Hill AFB got its name plus it house even more planes along with weapons and mechanics of the associated planes. Almost every inch of the building is alive with history from the aviation's infancy to its modern day power punch of firepower. Currently, it is sad to see that America has all of this firepower but has declined to use it more expeditiously with current events. But I am waxing poetic here folks.
Sit down and watch a film, read the walls and boards of those who have made history and just enjoy yourself.
Great place for kids because the outside displays are all open with no fences to bar you from getting up close. Just avoid hanging on the propellers.
The volunteer staff has done an amazing job of keeping the grounds clean and attractive and have tried their best to keep the pigeons at bay. Some of the planes are in need of some repair but they recently underwent painting and overhauls and are a joy to look at.
Bring a sun hat, plenty of water and a stroller for the younger ones and hang out in one of the best displays of American Aviation history in the region.
And if you are lucky, you will catch glimpses of F-22 Raptors, F-16 Falcons, F-15 Eagles, C-130 transports and more taking off from Hill AFB right behind the museum. There are even the occasional A-10 Warthogs and even the rarer B-1 Lancer. The newest attraction at Hill are the new F-35 Lightings but they are rarer still but they are there and take to sky. My personal favorite is the F-22 Raptor.
Have fun and enjoy yourself.

This is a great place to spend a couple of hours and learn about the history of some of the United States aircraft. The volunteers and VERY knowledgable and it is a great facility. Top notch! Do not miss it if you are in town.
I love to take my kids. They are so intrigued by the items on display. Great way to spend a rainy afternoon

places_url_reviews_title: This place just gets better and better!
places_url_reviews_comment: We have taken our kids many times here. We now take our grandkids and it has grown in size. They have also just recently painted many of the planes to look like they did back in the day. I love that they have an SR-71 Blackhawk and videos all about it.

This museum is a must for both history and aviation enthusiasts. The collection of aircraft covers the entire history of aviation. Visitors have a chance to see artifacts and planes representing pivotal moments in U.S. air power.
Excellent aircraft museum. It has many aircraft on display. You do not need a military ID to see the museum. If you like airplanes and their history, plan to stay the day.

This is a huge place, it has several planes from yesteryears, world war planes. Each exhibit has good description.There are some volunteers who will help you around the museum. Yes, it is free!!! Just a few seconds off the I-15 arterial Interstate highway, about 30 mins from Salt Lake City. Lots of Parking, places to eat, closeby.
They have a flight simulator, several flying machines like planes and helicopters in which people can go can really experience of being on one.
When we went here, we planned two places in a day, this Aerospace museum and the George Eccles Dinosaur Park, both in Ogden. Both are excellent for kids.

I was amazed at the sheer variety of aircraft shown in this museum. Outstanding displays, great audio/visual presentations, and wonderful staff of volunteers who are very knowledgeable about the aircraft. I especially enjoyed the rooms being divided up by era. The presidential planes were nice, and I particularly like the fact there is an area in the museum where you can conduct a ceremony (i.e. promotion or retirement ceremony) right there amongst the aircraft. This museum is a must-see for anyone in the Hill AFB area.

This museum is fantastic! Hangers full of full sized planes and flying machinery. My son was in absolute heaven here. Learned so much about the Air Force in Utah's history and even got inside some of the Jets! Interactive, educational and fun. If you go in the winter bring a sweater or coat, the hangers are basic metal buildings with heat but little insulation. Have fun!

places_url_reviews_title: Wonderful for kids to learn and run around!
places_url_reviews_comment: The airplanes outside were perfect for the kids to run around and play around. When we went inside we were surprised they had Veteran volunteers to talk to anyone interested or with questions. They also had a cock pit open and with guidance the kids were able to sit in it!! I would recommend going here to anyone especially if you have kids!! If you take a picnic, you can eat outside at the benches!

If you love airplanes, aviation and history, the Hill Aerospace Museum is definitely a "must visit." The collection of airplanes is astounding and best of all, they have an SR-71. This top secret aircraft is the ultimate in every aspect. Cool looking, amazing speed and fascinating history, it's THE plane to see and Hill has one!
One of the things I love is how you get a real sense of scale. We see planes flying above so often we forget that these amazing machines are really large and incredible feats of engineering. Being able to walk around, under and touch the aircraft gives you a great new perspective.
My only wish is that they would open up at least one aircraft and allow people to sit walk around inside and sit in the cockpit. It would definitely enhance the experience of the visit and make the visit very special. However, it's still a great place to visit and I encourage anyone in the Ogden area to allot a couple hours to see this fun museum.
As a female I loved looking at all the history that went along with all the awesome airplanes. Very impressive.

Impressive collection and it's still expanding and improving! Dramatic growth and improvement since the last time we were hear many years ago. The displays and signage in the main building are some of the best we've seen anywhere. Love the variety of aircraft and other related displays. Lots on Medal of Honor winners and other prominent veterans and significant people in Utah and Hill Air Farce Base history. Excellent Vietnam prisoner of war area and exhibit. Helps put the Hanoi Hilton and prisoner experience into perspective for those who do not know about it. Second building and outside are well done and improving, still adding additional areas. Loved the time spent here. Still could only really read and spend time with a fraction of the things here. Highly Recommended!

places_url_reviews_title: Great for an afternoon or all day!
places_url_reviews_comment: There is plenty to see here to keep you occupied all day. Multiple buildings, planes from all ages, and even a couple of nukes! It's free of charge but we always give them a donation. We come a couple times a year and bring the kids.
This is a must see for anyone who has any interest whatsoever in aviation or for love and respect for our military.

This place is great! The kids love seeing all the airplanes up close and i love being able to read about them. The seniors that volunteer here are knowledgeable and very helpful if you have questions.

places_url_reviews_title: A great display of machines that help keep us free.
places_url_reviews_comment: The Hill Aerospace Museum is a fascinating place to visit, and as an added bonus, it's free. There are displays from just about every period of air travel, but my favorites are from the WWII period, because I have some personal connections to WWII veterans (who saved the world).

A wonderful place to go
very helpful staff
Lovely collection of aircraft some really unusual things to see and worth going

places_url_reviews_title: For military plane fans and all children
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum is FREE and has military planes of all types. If you or your children have any interest whatsoever in military planes, this is the place
My wife grew up here and the last time she went in way when she was a kid! It was so cool! I loved all the planes and reading the stories of how they where used. It was a great visit!

I'm not really airplane lover..but I took the children and grandpa (who was a pilot in his younger years) he thoroughly enjoyed it and the children enjoyed themselves. I even enjoyed myself. It's very hot in the summer to see the outside exhibits. wear sunscreen. Plan to spend an hour and a half (at least that is how long we spent and it was sufficient

An amazing aeronautical museum reflecting on the inventory used by the USAF and other branches of the military. The staff are very helpful and friendly and have a passion for what they're doing. A must see if you come to Ogden.
There is plenty to see outside for aircraft, but the best and biggest displays are inside. It is well set up and maintained, great for any age.

This is a must see, it is full of cool planes and tons of history, hey it even has a Blackbird! Awesome place for the kiddies, great place if the weather is bad too as most of it is indoors. Loved it!

If you looking for a Museum type experience this is the place to go. You will find lots of Aircraft and Other Military Items. The staff and volunteers are great to talk to about the Museum and their personal experiences. This is a great family outing experience.

My 4 children and I enjoyed touring this museum and seeing the planes. There are planes outside that the kids can walk around to get a sense of how massive some of them really are. Inside we found great displays and knowledgeable guides. The gift shop is also very reasonably priced. I was able to find several souvenirs in the $0-$5 range which is hard to do at other museums.
Place goes on for miles. Plane after plane very exciting lots of stuff to look at. Interactive section for little kids was fun. Take your family you'll enjoy it.

places_url_reviews_title: Pretty fascinating to see the planes up close
places_url_reviews_comment: We like to go here to be able to let the kids stand near the wheels of the planes and see how big they really are. Quite a few airplanes are outdoors and it is amazing to see them up close. Inside there are mannequins of all the different uniforms etc throughout the years and more planes. It is very low key. It is spread between indoors and outdoors, so dress accordingly.

places_url_reviews_title: Fun for all in the family and kid friendly
places_url_reviews_comment: What a cool museum and a real treasure chest of history! Bring the kids and take your time. Wonderful aircraft and exhibits. They also have a fair amount of volunteers who have served int he past to answer questions and tell stories.
This is a great place to visit and see the different air planes and their history. I also like that it doesn't anything to go. My son likes to go about once a year.
Lots of great history and info. We all enjoyed it! Plan to spend some time here. There is about 2 large building and a very large area of planes outside. It can be cold and windy so plan accordingly.

This is a good air museum which is mid-sized. It has some aircraft you generally don't see elsewhere. There is a B-52 and an SR-71 as well as several other planes and helicopters. There are two buildings of exhibits and a welcome center with a small movie theater. There are also numerous planes outside on the grounds. It is definitely worth a visit.
This is a great stop for half a day of exploring old air craft from the USAF, as well as to learn some history. Friendly volunteers and easy access from I-15.

A wonderful experience whether you are young or old, an military buff or not. Aircraft galore (indoors and out) -- and one of the biggest collections in the West. Great stop for nostalgia as well. Great gift shop, informative displays and a wonderful way to spend a few hours or an entire day.
I love to visit with my kids. The volunteers there are wonderful and so willing to share their knowledge

places_url_reviews_title: Great place for kids to learn
places_url_reviews_comment: I visit this Museum a lot. We live close and I always see or learn something new. There are lots of planes and displays to see. SR-71 and B-52 as well as many others. Great place.

places_url_reviews_title: Meh. A family with littles may not be the target audience.
places_url_reviews_comment:
Our family of 5 visited the Hill Aerospace Museum, just outside of Hill AFB, on a chilly November Saturday morning. Admission is free. Many planes are on display outside the museum, to observe at your leisure. We signed the guest book and received a map of this huge place. Lots of war memorabilia inside, a movie that we didn't see (no posted show times), and many signs to inform. My husband and his father, a Navy veteran, especially enjoyed the fighter jet gallery. Our 5-, 3-, and 1-year-olds enjoyed the coloring station, manned by a volunteer who had a long chat with my father-in-law about the mission of the museum.
Overall, it felt dated. I sense that we were not the target audience, as there were not hands-on activities for children nor docents, though I saw plenty of volunteers around. Volunteers did make us directly aware of a demonstration that would be happening (of a generator, maybe?), but we were on our way out the door. Men seemed to be enjoying the museum in groups.

places_url_reviews_title: "PLANES AND PILOTS OF UTAH AND OUR AMERICAN HISTORY"
places_url_reviews_comment: I took 3 of my grandchildren to the Hill Aerospace Museum and we were there for 3 hours and enjoyed every minute of it. There is so much to see it is difficult to pinpoint just one thing, but it is an Eye opening experience.

places_url_reviews_title: A Must for Aviation Buffs and others
places_url_reviews_comment: Focused on World War Two and later aircraft, it is a great place to spend an afternoon. My favorites are the SR-71 and a Vietnam POW display.
A wonderful place to spend a day. Admission is free of charge but donations are accepted. It's great to look back in time at all of the old airplanes they have.

This museum will give you a broad spectrum of military aircraft, from pre WWII to modern day ultra high performance jet fighters. You will also see a rare SR-71 a previous super-secret high altitude speed demon of an aircraft type. The static displays of various type and size of aircraft can easily fill a whole day or more. The gift shop has excellent items for purchase to help remember your time spent.

places_url_reviews_title: Not like the Smithsonian or Wright Patterson, but nice
places_url_reviews_comment: A nice range of planes from and the history of aviation on what is now Hill AFB. Better than many museums I have been to but in some folk's eyes, limited. A nice stop if you are into aviation, military style.
Not very fun for small kids but a good time for teenagers and adults. It was very warm inside and was posted for no food and drinks but water would have been nice to have.

My husband, recently passed away at 88, was a WWII veteran and found the museum very moving. The vast array of planes outside and the displays inside were appreciated by him and my brother, who is a former Navy gunner.

places_url_reviews_title: I really enjoying going here with my Dad who was WW2 vet pilot
places_url_reviews_comment: The exterior of the museum has so many cool old planes and they are always adding planes. The inside of the museum has lots to see and the programs are great.

I was in the Ogden area on business and had some free time. This was definitely worth the visit. Tons of artifacts and airplanes from the Air Force to look at and definitely talk to the volunteers. I had the pleasure of speaking with Kenneth and he shared some amazing history and stories with me on the aircraft and people that flew them.
My husband and I took my 19 year old son who is about to join the Air Force. There is no fee but donations are very appreciated! My son was in awe of the place. We all learned things we didn't know.

places_url_reviews_title: Fabulous! Too much to see in one day
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum is truly awesome. Soooo much history. Way to much to see and read in one day. It's a must stop if you are in the area. A total gem and you would never suspect how far back the inside exhibits go from the outside! It's huge! There is no admission cost but if you are at all able, please make a donation while you are there. Let's keep this open for all future generations to see.

places_url_reviews_title: Great way to spend an afternoon
places_url_reviews_comment: I've been to the official Air Force museum at Wright Patterson AFB in Ohio and this one is very good by comparison. The history within the walls is humbling and kids both big n small will enjoy!
My son is obsessed with airplanes. We love coming here on rainy/snowy days. It is very laid back, just walk in and enjoy wandering around looking at the huge collection of planes.

places_url_reviews_title: Aviation exhibits of all genres and periods
places_url_reviews_comment: Not very knowledgeable of planes or their history, But plenty of opportunities to change that within and the spectacle alone is worth the stop. My 3 year old loved seeing everything.
My son LOVES coming to the museum. We are here about every 6-8 weeks, at least. It's free, and we always learn a lot of new things when we go.
The admission fee is by donation. Very large display of war planes and associated items. Give yourself a couple of hours at least to see this exhibit.
This is big. so standing for long time. whear the right shoes. There is a lot of history here and amazing authentic military artifacts.

While working in Logan, Utah my friends took me to this Museum as I had always wanted to see a real Flying Fortress, and while talking to the lady behind the counter, explaining I was from England and had made models of this plane as a child she asked me to "stay put" for a few minutes.
Then appeared with an elderly gentleman, who explained he used to be a ball gunner in a flying fortress, he then proceeded to take me to the plane, past the security cordon around the plane and showed me inside, I could not believe I was actually doing this, their are so many attractions to see but I only wanted to spend time with this machine.
Great Place to visit
Great Staff
and great chap who allowed me to live my boyhood dream

places_url_reviews_title: So much to see - don't miss!
places_url_reviews_comment: What a great air museum. We ran out of time because they closed. Give yourself a couple of hours at least if you appreciate seeing this type of history. The number of planes is phenomenal and the signage of each does a great job of explaining them. Don't miss when you visit Ogden.

places_url_reviews_title: Great Place for an Air Enthusiast to Visit
places_url_reviews_comment: The indoor section of the museum has been expanding over the years, and more planes are outside the building. They have a wide assortment of planes beginning with a World War I Curtis Jenny up to an SR71. They have a P51 Mustang, P38 Lightning, B17, B25, B29, B52, F16 and some MIGs, to mention a few. There is a large assortment of planes.

If you are interested in air planes or the history of aviation, then this is a great museum, It has many stories that can be read and has interesting facts about air planes that have been used in the military. There are many retired planes that are in the museum and it is a very hands-on type of display. There is quite a collection of air force memorabilia and I think most adults would enjoy the venue. I think that older children (older than 8) would appreciate this museum.
Dozens of vintage aircraft in two hangers and outdoor display. Great for kids. Friendly docents to answer your questions
I took my grandchildren between 4 and 10yrs. They enjoyed the outside planes and jets the best. I enjoyed the details involved with the history and it's beginnings.

The museum has two hangars, that are really packed with planes. Some bigger planes are in the outdoor area. If you are interesed in planes, you will be busy for two hours. But the best thing: the museum is for free!
Best place to take kids. Totally awesome. I 've taken my grandkids there several times and it is always worth the visit

You definitely need a few hours both on the inside and outside of the Hill Aerospace Museum in Ogden, Utah, north of Salt Lake City. A variety of planes are set on the field outside of the museum so you can sense the size as you walk around them . A pamphlet describing the planes is available at the door. Inside the free museum, volunteer Air Force vets will share the stories of the planes they flew. You will see neat rows of planes lined up, video historical footage of plane battles, displays and narratives explaining the start of the wars, use of the planes, etc. A narrative of both the Korean and Viet Nam War is also on display, a great history lesson for both adults and kids. You can view the size of POW cells and number of pilots captured, tortured and murdered during the Viet Nam War. View first hand the short-hand tapping for communication between POW'S. You don't have to be an airplane buff to enjoy this museum. You are able to see the progress in design and
technology in each generation of planes. Also on display, pilots uniforms and flight suits of different time periods. There is also a Museum Gift Shop on site.

Great aerospace museum. The weather is getting to some of the outside displays, but the inside displays are pristine. Lot's of aircraft and other related exhibits. Great volunteers who will answer your questions about the exhibits. If you are traveling through the Roy area on I-15, plan a lunch stop here. You can eat under the wings of an exhibit and then see the rest of the museum. Plan for at least an hour. The best part of all is it's free. They will always welcome donations to keep funding the special programs they put on.
Definitely a must see for aviation enthusiasts. We have gone a few times and it never disappoints. Mostly outdoors so be mindful of the weather.

places_url_reviews_title: Extremely impressed, definitely worth stopping by for an hour or more
places_url_reviews_comment: Located on the edge of Hill AFB, this is a surprisingly large museum going through the history of aircraft used by the Air Force. It is free (donation of $1/person suggested), and they close strictly at 4:30 for security reasons (the adjacent base closes at 4:30 sharp to civilians). You walk in, and it looks pretty unassuming, but then there are two HUGE hangars connected by a hallway with several dozen retired aircraft nicely laid out. The descriptions alongside each aircraft are excellent, as well, and I learned a lot in an hour. The sheer size of the airplanes and helicopters is a real wow factor for our two children (10 and 12), and I couldn't believe it was basically free to visit. About five minutes off of I-15, about 30 minutes outside of Salt Lake City.

places_url_reviews_title: It's so much bigger than it looks......lots to see
places_url_reviews_comment: There are so many planes on display here! It is informative and the artifacts are well displayed. Parking is easy, staff is friendly, and there is a small gift shop inside. A must-do in the Ogden area! There are is no set fee but donations are accepted.

places_url_reviews_title: Great History Past & Present of our Wonderful Air Force
places_url_reviews_comment: An excellent place to see the heritage of Hill Air Force Base and many, many aircraft from throughout the years. My favorite is the SR-71 which was classified all during my growing up years. One of my favorite things was meeting the many volunteer veterans, some of whom flew the very planes they were talking about. Just a great feeling of freedom and awe inspiring place to see a lot of very complex and interesting aircraft. The layout is perfect for touring the entire museum.

places_url_reviews_title: Why isn't the kids area open
places_url_reviews_comment: It's really cool to see these amazing jets up close. My 10 year old boy loved it. We really went for the kids area and it was closed. The weird thing is that sign outside of the children's area says it will be opening in spring of 2015. It's August. Disappointing. BUT there was a group of volunteers that helped the kids make paper helicopters and drop them off the balcony. That was a highlight for my kids. Great volunteers!
Very easy to reach, well worth it. From old to new there was something for everyone who loves airplanes!

Check this place out! As far as museums go, it's great. They've got a ton of historical planes including an SR71 blackbird. Sometimes they have retired pilots there to tell you about the planes. It's great!
We spent over two hours walking around outside and going inside the building! So much history here to read about and look at. Great for children to see! There is a nice gift store also.
HIll Aerospace museum is such an interesting museum for children, teens and parents. it is quite entertaining.

This is a reality fun place to visit. The planes are beautiful. There is so much historical information and it feels like you took a step back in time. Great place to take Scouting groups, out of town guests, and kids. Highly recommend!!
This is a great place to take the family. We enjoyed looking and learning. There are some planes outside but many many more inside. I can't believe it's free. Plan to spend several hours.

A fascinating tour of the history of American aviation with dozens of planes and hundreds of artifacts organized into two buildings with great interpretive placards all along the way. My fiancé really enjoyed it as he's into planes and military history, but it was an interesting tour for me, too, as someone with very little background knowledge on aviation. A great stop for people of all ages! Entrance is by donation and the front desk staff is friendly and will explain the various self-guided exhibits.

places_url_reviews_title: Execellent means for some historical aviation education
places_url_reviews_comment: A lot of interesting displays and old aircraft to see (and nicely arranged chronologically), so give your self the better part of the day at a minimum if you want to attempt to take it all in.

places_url_reviews_title: Great Aerospace Museum. Kids will enjoy the displays. Adults will to.
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a great place. Took my wife, daughter, brother and 3 of his kids to this place today. It was full of many planes, helicopters, missiles and displays. It was very easy to navigate through and plenty of space for people to see everything. It was very comfortable inside, it was not A/C, but it was plenty cool. The staff were very friendly. Great place to go with kids who love planes and other flying machines.

After a few hours of driving we were a bit tired so decided to stop to visit the museum. It was a great experience. There is an area outside with many planes, helicopters and fighters with explanations of what you are viewing. Inside there are 3 museums, 1 small and 2 rather large. Many, many planes, helicopters and fighter planes to see. Some you can see inside. Many types of bombs and missiles are on display. You can also see uniforms and many items related to the wars. There are veterans present to answer any questions you may have. We spent about 2 hours but more time could easily be spent. Multiple bathrooms and a gift shop. No fee to get into the museum.

Took 3 kids ages 5, 7 and 9. Arrived around 1pm on a Thursday. Quite crowded til about 2 and then it emptied out.
Lots to look at in the 2 large hangers. Lots to read. Like others have said not really much hands on stuff.
Cute little gift shop w/ very nice volunteers throughout.
Also an outside portion where you can walk under the big planes etc.
Museum is right off I15. easy to find.

Great family place to go. Every time my grandkids come to town from Iowa, they ask to go to the Aerospace Museum. The number of planes are great and it's free to go to. The volunteer are great and very knowledgeable, worth a visit even if it is out of your way. What a place.

places_url_reviews_title: Always Reminds Me of my Dad
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a great Free Museum for anyone who is an air plane buff. Great variety, especially if you go with someone who knows about airplanes. I took my kids many years ago when they were small and my son especially liked it. If you are lucky and in Utah in July there may also be an Air Show, so much fun and excitement

If you're the least bit interested in planes, the wars and/or Airforce, you must visit this museum. There is an outside plane exhibit (you can't go in the planes unfortunately) and two large hangers of inside exhibits (if the Utah summer is too warm for you).
Entry to the museum is free, but there is a spot for donations and a little gift shop should you wish to buy a little souvenir.
Nice place but out of the way. Can be quite boring though. They should make it more interactive. More rides more videos and let pple sit in them

This is a good museum, but the facility itself is not as nice as other museums that I have visited. Admission is free, but they do accept donations. There are a good number of aircraft on display and you can get up close to most all of them. They also have a nice model of an engine that moves and shows you how it operates. Additionally, there are some aircraft outside that you can view. But the museum buildings seem to be cooled by evaporative cooling and not A/C, so while it was cool enough, it wasn't as pleasant as it would have been if there was A/C. Also, the bathrooms were absolutely awful. The trash was overflowing and they were in poor condition and not very clean. The staff members that we came in contact with were okay, but not super friendly. They did have a nice gift shop, though, and plenty of parking.
This is a fascinating museum and so fun to see all the aircraft up close. My kids thought it was great. Definitely a fun outing everyone must do if in the area!

Very nice museum with some rare aircraft!
Including an sr71 blackbird! Lots of suprising aviation history. A great way to spend an afternoon!

We love taking the kids when its too hot to do anything outside or too much snow to do anything outside. This is perfect to go when you want to get out of the house and look at history. The collection is so huge!

Staff is very helpful, tons to see and do fun for all ages! We love it fun kids learning hands on area. And best part is it's FREE! But do leave a donation if you can as it all goes to help upkeep the museum.

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to learn and learn about history.
places_url_reviews_comment: Great museum at the air force base - lots bigger then it looks from the outside - lots to see and lots to learn. lots of retired veteran volunteers that will visit with you and share their stories - priceless.

places_url_reviews_title: One of the best collections anywhere
places_url_reviews_comment: Unbelievable collection of aircraft as well as other period correct exhibits (guns, trucks, etc). Easy access from the freeway, and there is no fee to get in. Easily one of the best air museums in the country.
A wonderful presentation and explanation for all of the aircraft in the museum. A must see for thrifty travelers.

It is nice to see the history of the old planes preserved. The really big planes are outside in the elements which is unfortunate. There is no admittance fee, just a donation is recommended. It is run by volunteers (mostly retired military service persons). There is a gift shop as well.

places_url_reviews_title: Great air museum, not so much "space"
places_url_reviews_comment:
We have visited a lot of air museums and this was one of the best. Looks are deceiving - there are dozens and dozens of aircraft indoors to view. Volunteer docents are on hand to answer questions and offer insights on many of the vehicles, even on week days.
Located near the Hill Air Force Base, this museum has real aircraft we've never seen in person before. And it's free! (Donations accepted of course)

Great Museum. We live two miles away and it's still something to see. My husband is Air Force Reserves, so we definitely support this and enjoy going to learn more about our history. Go if you haven't before.

places_url_reviews_title: You will need two days to really see it.
places_url_reviews_comment:
Well thought out exhibits. There are two indoor exhibit halls, one mostly early aviation to WWII, then the next building Korea, Vietnam, and miscellaneous.
I found the WWII exhibits very interesting and informative not only on major items, but lesser known aspects of the conflict. I had not known that US soil (Alaska, TH) had been bombed. I knew about the fire/bomb balloons, but not that there were that many.
I think there are 20 aircraft outside. I did not have time to check it out.
As I said in the title, two days wold be needed to really take it all in. I guess I would suggest the early aviation to WWII building, then a break and look outside. Go home and think about it, then on the next visit, look at what you wanted to see more of, then go on to the next building, and spend more time outside.
Oh, and don't forget the gift shop.

This is the second time visiting this museum. My husband is retired military and a big history buff and really enjoyed his time here as did I. They have a great airplane display and we had the honor and privelege of talking with 3 veterans who were volunteers there...what a delight! And the woman at the front desk was absolutely lovely. Everyone should visit this museum especially kids.

places_url_reviews_title: Premier Aviation Museum (and its free): Hill Aerospace Museum
places_url_reviews_comment:
This is a superb aerospace museum and its amazing that it is free (note - donations are welcome). We first went after it closed for the day (not checking the hours in advance) and just seeing the amazing planes in the field meant that yes - the next day we were there when it opened. We first went out and saw the amazing planes outside. Its a wealth of military history.
We then went to the theater in the museum and watched some of the very good aviation documentary movies there.
Then, we went to see the museum. From the outside it doe not look as large as it is. There is also very good information on the different Wars such as Korea and Vietnam, including a display on a POW prison.
On the day we were there they were also setting up for a military presentation of medals to some military people (we saw the military men and women arriving for the presentation.)
There is also a hall of fame display with excellent write ups and pictures.
We have visited a number of aviation museums, and this is one of the best we have been to. If interested in the military or in aviation history, its well worth a visit.
Parking is close to the museum also in a free parking lot.

This museum has done a fantastic job of gathering historical artifacts regarding military actions in the sky in wartime as well as in times of peace. In some parts of the museum they even recreate POW camps. So cool! Several hours can easily be spent wondering around this great place.
Great collection of aircraft on display over 90 planes housed inside and out, this is a great attraction and staffed by volunteers, we had a really enjoyable visit here and got lots of great pictures

We live near the AF museum at Robins AFB GA, one of the finest aircraft museums in the country. But the Hill AFB museum has the nicest display of WWII aircraft I think I have ever seen, and the Vietnam collection is wonderful too. They are wonderfully setup for children/school groups too. Volunteer staff is to be applauded for their work, and presence to answer questions, GREAT Experience.

places_url_reviews_title: A Worthwhile Visit If You're In The Area
places_url_reviews_comment:
Just outside the gate to Hill Air Force Base, the museum has a good collection of aircraft, primarily World War II through Vietnam. There are two galleries inside, and larger aircraft are stored outside. A few aircraft can't be seen in many other places, such as the SR-71 Blackbird. There are also replicas and casings of various bombs and rockets, to include a replica of the first atomic bomb.
There is also a lot of factual information on a number of people who played a significant part in either the development of aviation in Utah and/or Hill AFB, or were in the service from the state. Small alcoves showcases the POW experience in Vietnam and the WWII WASPs.
There are a number of audio-visual displays, explaining various aspects of Hill AFB, the Vietnam conflict, and aviation in general.
Admission if free, although a modest donation is suggested.
The only real shame is that they don't have indoor space for the aircraft currently displayed outside - the weather is giving the planes quite a beating.
Touring the museum is well worth the time.

I have been here many times for retirements of my fellow brothers and sisters of the United States Uniform Services, but this last time I was able to take some time and really enjoy a small part of the grand tribute to a great nations heritage. Not only did I get to bask in the ah of the planes but had a great visit with one of the curators (people who recovered and helped with the restoration) of several of the displays. If you have little one of all ages (3-103) this is a sight for their eyes. Come in and see the planes and maybe have a chance to talk to some of the men and women who worked on and flew these preserved icons. There are planes inside and out so don't miss visiting them all. Enjoy and make sure to thank the volunteers who keep the doors open.

Great displays of aircraft from all eras along with other war related vehicles and armament. Very informative details of Air Force / Army Air Corp personnel and their missions and aircraft. Fascinating and captivating. Thank you to all who gave and served. Thank you to those that are working continuously to preserve our history.

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to learn about Air Force history
places_url_reviews_comment:
Last trip there was with grandkids, so their attention spans limited the time we were able to see each display, and for some reason they weren't interested in the same planes and ground equipment I was. Still, it's something they remember and want to see again.
Great effort has been given by all the volunteers who restored the aircraft and other displays, and accurate information is provided for everything in the museum. For those who wish a hands-on esperience, there are dozens of historic aircraft outside the building. Otherwise the aircraft inside are wisely protected from possible abuse by being roped off; visible but not touchable, as they should be.
The price is right; donations accepted happily, but no charge for entrance.
Enjoyed the museum. Took about 2 hours to go through it all. Staff at the information desk were extremely knowledgeable, answering all of our questions. Loved the displays...
This is a very well-done museum. There are lots of interesting planes and displays. For anyone interested in aviation this place is a gem.

places_url_reviews_title: Thought we'd stop for an hour.... 4 hours later.
places_url_reviews_comment: An exceptional museum right on the freeway in Ogden. Admission by donation. Two huge buildings filled with planes, memorabilia and information.
