Outside of the building are aircraft just amazing to be able to walk up and appreciate the size of them. Kids will love running around outside to burn off energy. I suggest you go through the first gallery, have a break (no restaurant here sadly - just a gift shop) and come back to do the second gallery. You don't want to become "planed out". Really a fantastic exhibit. Well worth the stop. There's even a Walmart close by for those who like to camp free.....

This museum is larger than it appears. There are many aircraft to see, each with a description of its historical impact as well as its specifications. Exhibits are both inside and outside. Allow 2 to 3 hours to see everything. The volunteers who run the place are anxious to get out at day's end and tend to close up earlier than advertised.

places_url_reviews_title: Free, fun, great kid center, and did I mention planes!!!
places_url_reviews_comment:
Great place to visit. Free! If you are local or not, take 10 mins or a few hours.
Many events and great children learning center. Find the times for the children's center lessons. They are great fun. We have made rockets there too. Flight simulators, and much more.
They have planes from all eras, spy planes, and if you time it right you can sit in some of them.
I have taken my kids many times. They love it. Good place to start a traditions.

My husband is an airline pilot and of course loves the Museum, but our kids love it as well. It is also a great place to take out of state family and friends who come for a visit. Love the Aerospace Museum!!

There is an indoors and outdoors display of all types of aircrafts.
The museum is free but take donations. The inside is in two sections with extras. the first section is a eclectic collections of everything Air Force very informative. Hallways between sections honors person of significance of aviation. The second section was more modern with jets and helos. A nice half day or more of information and static displays.

I've driven past this museum countless times and visited it about 10 years ago. I was in the area and had the opportunity to visit once again and I don't know if it was really worth my time. The history and planes are amazing, but quite frankly there's not been a lot of change in the past 10 years. There's a marked difference in the planes from the interior displays to the exterior and while I understand the weather can be hard on them, it would be nice to see the larger outdoor exhibits better cared for.
I enjoyed the visit and had a good time explaining the history surrounding the planes to my kids, but it may be some time before I return.

Nice museum plenty of aircraft to see in 2 hangers old & newer jets one from the presidential fleet & some big jets outside including my favourite one the b1 bomber. It has a nice little gift shop but unfortunately in my opinion it needs couple of vending machines for food so you need to bring your own & have a picnic in amongst the jets outside. Also jet fighters & other aircraft were flying out of Hills air force base so it was an added treat to see them it is a great way to spend half a day at no cost just a donation.

I visited this museum when I came to visit my grandparents in Roy,Utah. There is no entrance fee, so you don't need to pay anything for it. they have a huge selection of airplanes, military history and other stuff. If you are in the area, you should definitely visit it. you can easily spend half a day there and learn a lot about our country's military aviation history.

There were so many things to see here so if you love planes you have to visit. Two huge hanger's filled with well kept old planes and massive ones outside that you can walk around and under. The admission is free but donations are a good idea and it has a cute little gift shop. No food but place for a picnic under the planes.

places_url_reviews_title: Great Place for Anyone Who Loves Planes
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum is an amazing place for anyone who loves aircraft of any kind. It has everything from early planes to war planes, to space craft. It even has an old Air Force One jet. When you go, don't go through the first building and think that you are finished-there is a second building directly behind the first one that is just as good. The admission to this place is free. It is worth a few hours if you are ever in Ogden area. The only thing that could make this place better was if you could go inside some of the planes.

The museum is just through the Gate, at the Roy freeway exit/entrance. Part of my office went here on a field trip. Possibly because there were 15 or so of us (I didn't make the arrangements, so I'm not sure), a museum guide escorted us throughout the building and gave us a great deal of information about each stop. It's really quite a huge museum, full of interesting planes, etc. We didn't have time to see the airplanes outside.

I'd previously visited this museum with my daughter, but I had little boys staying with me and I thought they would really enjoy it. They are ages 9 and 3 and both of them loved looking at the airplanes. This is a free museum and will take you about an hour-90 minutes to get through. The inside of the museum is more informative than the displays outside. I'd like to know why the planes outside are important, or maybe wish they had been labeled to let us know what kind of plane they are. We noticed one of Gail Halvorsen's (The Candy Bomber) planes outside and since kids are becoming familiar with that story, it would be nice if there had been something identifying it. It had his name on the side, but if you didn't know his name, you wouldn't make the connection. Anyway, small critique aside, we had a nice time.

I'm always interested in seeing aircraft, but unfortunately the display leaves much to be desired.
The aircraft in the outdoor display are all in bad condition, rusting away, with barely any explanatory material. Maybe one sign with the aircraft name on every other one.
The aircraft inside are better preserved but also hardly any information is supplied (although more than outside).
If you're looking for a very educational visit - this is not the place.

places_url_reviews_title: Airforce jets you can almost touch
places_url_reviews_comment: While you can't actually touch the planes, you can get within inches of F16s, A10s, special ops helicopters, spy planes, and much more. Getting there can be confusing, as although the museum is only 30 seconds off the freeway, it is on Airforce property and is surrounded by a tall fence, however you don't travel through the base to get to it (turn left when you see the checkpoint at the Roy gate). There is a lot of room for kids to run around at the museum, with actual military planes (not replicas or models) parked in both outdoor as well as indoor galleries. They even have benches and picnic tables under the wings of some planes, so it is a great place to relax and learn about military history. I particularly enjoy the museum because the open nature of the exhibits allows adults and interested kids to read the signs near the planes and munitions while still keeping an eye on the more energetic companions who rush to see the next plane or helicopter. While outside you'll likely notice in-service military planes (fighter-jets as well as cargo and surveillance planes) flying overhead to and from the adjoining Hill Airforce Base.

The museum is close to the freeway. So, if you are just passing through and need a stop, this is the place to do it. The museum is large and full of history that really connects you with what you are seeing. This is great for all ages. It is free, although they do take donations to help keep the facility running. Don't miss this one.

With all of the great aircraft in the hangers -- several times a day a guided tour should be made available. There are folks located here and there to answer questions, but a more structured experience should be offered.

places_url_reviews_title: Get A Map, Go Early, Enjoy!
places_url_reviews_comment: This was our second visit and we were too tired to enjoy it as much as we enjoyed our first tour. We got lost getting there - must have tried every entrance to Hill A.F.B. before finally finding the right one! It was close to closing time by the time we finally found it so we had to rush. My husband wanted to see the SR71, so he rushed in to see it and I limped along more slowly and found a handy place to sit down, then another handy place, then another. I didn't see nearly as much as I would have liked - I really enjoyed it the other time I was there and I hope we get back again soon when I'm not so tired. Once again my husband was thrilled with the place, even though our time was so limited. The staff was very friendly and helpful. The place was very clean - even just minutes before closing time! I recommend it to anyone who enjoys learning the history of the Air Force and flying. It's a great place - but check out how to get there ahead of time - and when they say they close at 4:30 they mean they LOCK the GATES at 4:30 so you'd better be gone by then!
Being an Air Force brat and seeing lots of places. This is in the top 3 in the nation. #1 being the Air Force Museum in Dayton. The next one may be this or the annex for the Smithsonian
Wonderful displays. Clean and easy to visit. Interesting history from several eras. Friendly and helpful staff.

This is a great place to spend an entire afternoon with hundreds of displays and activities. We have visited it many times, and every time we leave the children ask when they can go back. As adults we love to see the old planes and read the history behind them. You HAVE to make this a destination when you visit Ogden.

places_url_reviews_title: This local museum with easy access from I-15 has SR 71 and Globemaster C124 plus real war aircraft inside
places_url_reviews_comment: This Air Force Museum is one of the best in the west with knowledgeable volunteers pointing out the history and purpose of the various aircraft and systems used. This is a very worthwhile place to gain experience of how Hill AFB played a part in past wars, and is an vital part of today's Military roles.

For anyone interested in the history of flight, this is a great place to spend an afternoon. They even have an SR71C Blackbird - the only one of its type ever made, and it has a rude nickname.
Once or twice a year they have events where you (or your grandkids) can sit in the cockpits of some of the planes. Busy days, but worth it.
The museum itself is in two parts; an outdoor area where the *really* big planes are, and the indoor area, which is mainly fighters and helicopters. I recommend you try to go during the spring/summer, when the weather is nice enough to wander outside.
Highly recommended.
This museum is one of the best around it is well maintained and taking care of people of work there are very friendly and knowledgeable I would come here it to any in the western United States

I lived in Ogden for 30 years and never went to the museum. On a recent visit I took my grandson one afternoon. What a great surprise it was, we spent the whole afternoon. First it much bigger than I thought it was and the displays are very well done. Again I was impressed at the number of aircraft variety they have on display. If you enjoy aircraft with some history don't miss it!

I think I have been here 3 times. Every time family comes to visit we go. My kids love it and the place is free. It runs off of donations if im not mistaken. But what else can you do for free and have the kids constantly saying......Daddy look at this! Daddy look at that! Well worth the time in my book. They even have the SR 71 Blackbird.
What a great find. The volunteers were knowledgeable and friendly. Great exhibits and history. Well worth spending an afternoon or morning
Good employee help, educational, lots of airplanes, a must see. Very interesting to see the different types of airplanes and read the detail about them.

If you enjoy old WWII memorabilia this is the place for you. They have many aerospace exhibits along with several other odds and ends. The smaller planes are inside and the bigger ones are outside. You can't go in them, though.
There are outside picnic tables and the docents all seem to be WWII veterans and are quite knowledgeable about everything there. They even had a wheelchairs available for those who would have a hard time walking through.
Parking is easy and it is free.
If you are a big WWII history buff, you could spend hours there. My husband and brother did. Otherwise, just bring a book and chill out among the great exhibits after you've taken a walk through.

We visited when my Aunt and Uncle came to see us. My husband is in the Air Force, and my uncle is retired military so they both enjoyed the history. I was impressed at the collection. They also had a section of the museum devoted to children, with a few activities for them to participate in. I would definitely go back.

places_url_reviews_title: A wonderful place to learn some important history.
places_url_reviews_comment: We took our children and grandchildren there for a visit. Everyone loved it and thought the displays of memorabilia, planes, and exhibits were very informative and interesting. It was in July, but the rooms were kept cool and comfortable for the many visitors. I would love to go back and see more someday!
Good price and very interesting for kids! Nice to visit in the summer months when the weather is warm! You can get great pictures!

places_url_reviews_title: Always something new, a regular place to visit
places_url_reviews_comment: Lost of history and lots to see, You really need a good day to see it all. Would be nice if you could get something to eat here.

This is such a great place for kids, teens or adults. It's also free! :-) I love the history, my kids love the planes and it gives them a better idea of what our military has done to help our country and others too. Helpful people all around and a fun gift shop too.

places_url_reviews_title: Tons to see tons to learn
places_url_reviews_comment: WOW!!!! It starts outside but inside is amazing. There are so many planes in here it's almost to much. It is very hard to get a picture of an individual plane. Outside of complaining about that, this place is great!! Wasn't crowded, staff was helpful and informative. Nice gift shop. Easy place to kill an afternoon, or more!!

places_url_reviews_title: One of the highlights of our trip
places_url_reviews_comment:
We spent 3 hours at the museum but could easily have spent and entire day. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot of walking.
Fantastic exhibits both indoors and outside starting from the early days of aviation to current military history. Many planes and exhibits of war era history. Another exhibit room housed displays of various types uniforms of the pilots thru the years.
Lots to see and enjoy for the entire family.
The Hill Aerospace Museum is a rich history of military aircraft from prop to jet. Hill has and still plays an important role in the defense of the USA. Kids of all ages will enjoy their visit.

places_url_reviews_title: A Hidden Gem of a Museum
places_url_reviews_comment: If you are in the Salt Lake District & like your planes this museum should not be missed. All types of war planes in two huge hangers & on outside display. Great history of American wartime aviation.

Went to take some info I had on the aircraft and found it to be as good as the one at Wright Patterson Field in Ohio. NO JOKE!!! Everyone there is very helpful. A must see if you are in the area and love flying and history at it's best. Perry Willard
A lot of jets, older planes. A clean museum, an areas outside to see additional planes with a gorgeous view of the mountains!

I drive past this place on holiday and couldn't believe it! It was great and to top it all off, it's free! It was gret to sit outside and have a pic-nic under the wing of a huge jet. They have a gret variety of planes and you can get up close to them. Yeah it's full of the usual Uncle Sam Patriot stuff but if you look beyond all of that, it's amazing to think that these planes were nook bed in helping to create a more free world. I loved seeing a piece of the iconic White Cliffs of Dover there. It was pretty sweet. My only down side is how it says that World War 2 started in 1941, it didn't, it started in 1939. For any nationality, this place is super fun and you can spend ages just marvelling at its grandeur! Definitely worth a visit if you're up in Ogden!

if you are looking for an educational and fun experience plan a visit to the Hill Aerospace Museum. They have a remarkable collection of aircraft inside and out to view. The museum provides interesting facts about the history of aviation and air combat. Many retired Airmen volunteer at the museum. Stop and thank them for their service and take time to hear their stories. It enhances my visit and increases my appreciation for those that serve our country. The museum is free to the public however I suggest making a small donation to keep this great Utah museum open for all to enjoy.

places_url_reviews_title: A must see for some basic history lessons.
places_url_reviews_comment: Being in such close proximity to Hill AFB does have some unique benefits like this awesome FREE museum. From historic planes and bombers to a walking history through many wars and conflicts, you will leave a bit more knowledgeable about both U.S. and World History.
We took 4 children and they were all fascinated with everything. They have a children's area with flight stimulators and fun things for them to do. They didn't want to leave.
The museum is free and it is fabulous. Plan about 2 hours. Wear comfortable shoes because there is a lot of walking. Well worth the time to go.

It’s quite large. It has indoor displays and outdoor displays.
The building you enter houses the gift shop, uniform display and theater and the building is connected to the first indoor airplane display and that building is connected to another indoor airplane gallery. The walkway between the two indoor galleries showcases the Utah Aviation Hall of Fame. Each airplane has a “fact sheet” type of posting that shows the name, manufacture, engine size, range, etc. as well as its history.
I went with my history/military buff pilot husband and he loved it. He said he saw a couple of airplanes he had never seen in other well known air museums. Some exhibits make you deeply appreciate those airmen and airwomen who fought for their (and our) lives while confined for hours in tight and awfully uncomfortable looking seats as well as the ground/support crews that provided infallible workmanship.
We saw some families with smaller children and the little guys are all happy and in awe with the exhibits. Speaking of families, there is an outdoor picnic area you can drink and eat while watching airplanes. You can’t bring food or drink inside but it’s ok to eat/drink outside and there was a beverage vending machine.
The title of this review is coming from a displayed F/RF-4C’s decal: F/RF-4C PHABULOUS PHANTOMS PHOREVER (see the photo).
Put on a pair of comfortable shoes and go.

If you are in the Northern Utah area then you should spend half a day visiting the Hill Aerospace Museum. They have hundreds of aircraft on display for a replica Wright Brothers flyer to a SR-71. Lots of other displays besides aircraft to see as well. Typically there are Air Force Veteran Retirees in the museum area to show you around and discuss the aircraft. Go see the Hill Aerospace Museum, you won't be disappointed!

places_url_reviews_title: Neat planes, too bad you can't see inside them.
places_url_reviews_comment: I enjoyed seeing all the planes and reading all of the info on them. I really wish they made it so you could see inside them. Especially the really large planes outside. That would put this museum over the top. I also liked all of the patches in the gift shop. For a free museum (donations accepted), this place is amazing!
The museum is both fun and informative. It is worth the time. We saw airplanes that we would never have been able to view. The volunteers who are the docents are quite passionate and knowledgeable.
Stop here to see the exhibits at the hill Air Force Base and it is just incredible them on the planes I haven't hear it's a must-see stop

places_url_reviews_title: If in the area see it.
places_url_reviews_comment:
We just happened to come across this as we drove up the freeway, decided why not and sure glad that we did.
Both my 20 year old son and myself were very impressed. It is well worth a visit. We were there for 3+ hours and could of spent more time.

I've been here countless times and I am in awe of everything that is here. Aircraft from all eras of flight. Come visit here and take in the impressive and mind-blowing ingenuity it took to create these places. Also take in the history and how much impact they had. From the Wright Brother's plane to an SR-71 Blackbird to an B-52, F-16s, F-15s, and more. YOu could easily spend an afternoon here. There is also a kids area for them to explore what flying is all about.

I've been to over a dozen air museums in the last couple of decades. Being an ex-pilot and the son of a military pilot, planes have been an interest all my life. And this museum really touched a chord. It has them all, from some obscure models to the latest in military examples of planes that have been our protectors. They have transporters, fighters, bombers, drones, helicopters, antiques, and even a lot of displays which show what pilots wore, how they were housed in the various conflicts that our country has been involved in. An incredible indoor array, and an awesome walkway with some of the more gigantic of the planes that have flown for us. And we had three of my great-grandchildren with us, and they even enjoyed all those planes... Come see if you're in Utah, it's awesome...

Wow! What an incredible amount of planes! Took the family there on a whim and I hadn't been there since I was a young boy. It most certainly has changed since. There was sooooo much information about the planes and people and equipment. We all learned a lot and could've stayed a bit longer if we had arrived earlier. We will have to go again to see everything more in depth. I highly recommend going. You will see and learn much about our history and military. Incredible!!! Lots of cool things in the gift store too!

Very nice AF museum with a large selection of aircraft and associated equipment. Great for families as the kids are usually more interested than some of the adults. Take your family in and let them experience some USAF history and get a feel for what your tax dollars do and what the fine military families have done for years. Entry fee is a donation...doesn't get any better than that (but don't be cheap!).

Awesome just awesome. If you like military planes you need to come here. Great place to learn about military planes from the past and some of the people who flew them. Always take out of town family and friends here when they come to visit.

This Museum is a great experience for the entire family. The real planes and jets are fun to see in person. There are also items from history such as missiles, bombs, uniforms, and weapons.
There is a learning center for the kids. They can experience flight simulators and different science activities. We had a great time!
This place is great. Friendly and informative staff with great planes on display. Did I say it was free to get it.
Great airplane museum for anyone interested in airplanes. Great for kids. Big range of planes from old to new. And it's FREE.

It took me a long time to finally visit this great Air Force museum. Driving by, it seems to be just a few planes outdoors with a small building. But one you enter the doors you start to realize that it is a lot bigger on the inside. A lot bigger! Amazing displays cover the evolution of military aviation from Wright flyers to SR-71 Blackbirds and much, much more. Best, it's free!

places_url_reviews_title: Standing next to those big planes is amazing!
places_url_reviews_comment: Took my boys ages 7 and 5. We started outside where you could walk around and look at the different types of planes. Some were so huge and it was crazy to be standing right next to them and seeing how small you are in comparison. The boys loved it! The only thing they were disappointed with is the fact that they couldn't go inside any of them. There are a lot of them and it can be quite a walk, so bring some water if it's a hot day. They have paved sidewalks all throughout, so you can bring strollers or wagons for little ones. We then went inside the museum building where there is a small gift shop and a room with other planes and other things to look at. They had replicas of nuclear bombs which was fascinating to see. It opened up opportunities to talk to my kids about war and the men and women that serve our country and protect our freedom. There is no admission fee to see any of this, but they have places where you can put in donations to help with the upkeep of this attraction. They also have volunteers there to answer any of your questions. Was a fun morning and would highly recommend.
A word of caution - much of their printed brochures found at area hotels and visitor centers indicates Hill is open Sunday. It is not.
A wonderful history of our jet planes and the progress that they have made today. Gives you a history of the strength of our military.

places_url_reviews_title: Free, a lot of history, cool family outing idead
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a fun outing when it's too hot/cold to do anything outdoors. My son LOVES planes and helicopters and the museum has a lot of displays. It is a lot of walking as it has a lot of planes, jets, helicopters, displays, etc. So if you have younger kids definitely bring strollers or wagons. We all got into it- and for free, can't beat that! The gift shop has astronaut food as well which is kind of cool. I think all kids, regardless of age or gender, can have an interesting time here.
Great museum of military flight history. They exhibits are very educational and gives one a great overview of they history of flight

My family and visitors loved the museum, I walked around saw the planes and was ready to go! My family wanted to see everything! They spent three hours wandering around. The veterans that were there the day we went were quite knowledgable and their stories were entertaining.

We took our young grandchildren, ages 4 & 7, to see the museum after our grandson spotted the outdoor plane exhibit from I-15. We started with the two indoor exhibit halls, then went outside to see the planes around the grounds. There were easily more adults there than children, so don't be put off if you're traveling without kids. The museum is free, the gift shop offers a nice selection of airplane-related gifts, and there are bathrooms in the main building. If you're planning to stay a while, especially in the summer, pack cold drinks as there are none sold in the store and the only soda machine outside was out of service. As a bonus, the outdoor area offers a great view of the Wasatch Mountains. Oddly, the elderly museum volunteers were cranky on the day we visited. Overall, we had a good time.

One of the best military aircraft museums I have ever seen. It takes a half a day to see all the planes. They had displays of all five aircraft my father in law flew in WW2. I would recommend this to any history or airplane fan.

places_url_reviews_title: If you like planes and history, this is a must see!!
places_url_reviews_comment: I've been an admirer of planes from different eras. WWII planes are my favorite. Where else can you find a B17, B25, and a B24 all in one hangar? This place does!The collection is priceless!!
A fun and educational experience, especially for those who have an interest in aviation. Ideal for any age.

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to see if you planes
places_url_reviews_comment: It was worth to go and see this museum and i love planes from a different time, i love every plane, i would love to go again soon

Truly a world class museum. Restored planes to see and walk around. (Even a P47 like my father-in-law flew in the Pacific theater of operations in WWII.) Well worth the time to see and it is easy to get on and off the I-15 Freeway
Whenever we have out of town visitors we always come here. Most are former military and/ or pilots and they always enjoy the museum. Please leave a good donation, it is costly to keep up.
This is worth an aftenoon visit. It is a very well done airplane museum. There a wide variety of airplanes from a replica of the Wright Flyer to SR 71 Blackbird

I visit this museum every two years. It usually takes me about 2 to 3 hours to see all of the aircraft and other exhibits.. The facility is very large and houses many different types of Aircraft both inside and outside.
I prefer to take the free guided tours that are hosted by retired military veterans. They do a great job.
Great planes, helicopters, military clothing, and other items are displayed in the museum.
I would recommend this museum to families, veterans, and active military You will it love it and the admission is free to all.

places_url_reviews_title: Great stop if in the area.
places_url_reviews_comment: This Museum has improved alot over the past few years, if your in the area I would highly recommend stopping by.
Excellent and free. I've been to several USAF museums and this stands along with any as an outstanding display.
This museum is fantastic! Great helicopters and lots of history. Took my sisters kids and they had a great time too.

We stopped by to visit the museum during an afternoon off from a business trip. Since our business is aviation oriented we were all interested in this stop. The facility is very large and well laid out. There are docents that help explain the exhibits and relate their own experiences in the aircraft as they are all retired military. I made it a point to thank them for their service. There's a small exhibit about the Vietnam military POWs and their experiences...unfortunately the unsupervised, small, noisy children were a distraction...not their fault...
The larger aircraft outside give you a very good idea of the sheer size of some of these aircraft.
All-in-all it was a good visit.

There are A LOT of planes here. We visited 10 years or so ago and there is a nice addition to the museum. You can easily spend 2+ hours here if you are at all interested in planes. There is a 40 minute long children's demonstration with flight simulators, science experiments and even blocks for the littlest ones! The museum in set up nice, interesting information. I watched several short video's at different displays that were nice. The planes outside are HUGE. The one thing we were disappointed in was the "movie" in the little theater. It is terrible. It's very short, the into music takes longer than the clips, there are about four clips, and it doesn't hold up to the rest of the museum. Skip it, unless you need to rest your feet.

For the price (free) it was perfect. My son loved running around declaring all the planes to be his "favorite". We will probably go back later this year- they have one day where they let you climb in some of the airplanes and have some flying overhead.

I guess if you love love love old planes so much and name model planes or something then this is a really cool place. It was quiet and kinda depressing. The theater shows a pretty crappy movie that is only a few minutes long. I was bored of the place after 20 minutes. I did notice that some kids loved it but I think most are bored within 30 min. It's free so that's a plus. Maybe worth a stop if you're in the area but not a destination. There are a lot of planes and they put effort into the place but its just kinda boring.
To be fair, I have never been to an aerospace museum other than this, so perhaps it is relatively good? But I got bored quickly. If it wasn't free, I'd rate it 2 stars.

There is a LOT to see, and our grandchildren especially enjoyed the old WWII planes that were outside. Inside there is also lots to see--too much to do in one day if you have young children with you. Lots of history.

places_url_reviews_title: Great to spend some time there.
places_url_reviews_comment: Seeing some of the planes brought back memories from my time in the AF as an Air Traffic Controler. Some very nice exhibits.

Our children loved the aviation museum. We were surprised about how large the museum is. We really enjoyed the jets, they have an sr71 blackbird, F-16 hornet, and many other newer jets on display. Interactive experiences were ok for kids. Kids will enjoy the sheer size of the jets and adults will enjoy learning about aviation history.

Excellent collection of airplanes thru the ages.
Inside and outside, so plenty of room to roam!
Well organized and inspiring!
Be sure to give yourself a break from skiing and check in out.
I was in the Air Force so this place really touch my heart. If you like planes you will not be disappointed here...

The Hill Aerospace Museum is located just to the west of Hill Air Force Base in Ogden UT. It's open five days per week (Tue-Sat) from 9:00 am to 4:30 pm.
While admission is free, they accept donations. The majority of the work restoring the aircraft and manning the information booths is conducted by volunteers. Many of them are USAF veterans who actually flew the aircraft on display; their wealth of knowledge is impressive and their stories make your visit that much more special.
The museum has an extensive display of flying gear, dating back to the first aircraft in military service, from US and other military services. There are several sections to the museum. Several of the larger aircraft and missile systems are on permanent display outside the museum. The uniforms are the first display you'll see upon entering the facility. The first large hangar contains exhibits from the Wright Brothers through the Korean War. A walkway containing photos and bios of prominent military aviation pioneers connects you to the modern jet age hangar. Also located in the museum is a learning center, where children can learn about aviation and a classroom, full of carefully crafted model aircraft, for group presentations.
if you'd like to coordinate a group visit, the museum oftentimes can secure a dedicated guide for your party. The phone number is 801-777-6818. While the guide is normally one of their volunteers, they are also able to secure an active duty Air Force pilot from Hill AFB to lead you through the museum.
While you can walk through the entire facility in about an hour, I recommend allocating at least three hours in order to take in all the exhibits.
We spent several hours here and want to go back because we didn't see everything. It was very interesting. My husband has an interest in planes and piloting, I don't. But we both enjoyed it.

places_url_reviews_title: A Must see in the Top of Utah
places_url_reviews_comment: It's free!!! Its FUN and its great for all ages. It has a lot of fun facts that you may or may not know about planes, war, military. Kids love it, and adults do too!!!

I don't know about other aerospace museum, but this one is GREAT! Along with the planes, copters etc. there is a whole bunch of military doodads on display. The history runs deep and the stories told by the local Veteran volunteers are not to be missed. My boys and I go every year, and it NEVER get old. Excellent!

Air Force museums are always a treat. They have access to free aircraft, after they have reached their end, so they are able to have millions of dollars of hardware for pennies. They also attract former aviators, maintainers and enthusiasts that will tell you everything you could ever want to know. Give them an afternoon to fill your head with stories, your camera with images of battle tested war machines and your heart with their stories of sacrifice and service with honor.

Great for kids and adults, especially if you like aircraft stuff. I especially liked the aircraft with weaponry that is aged. This was really enlightened by the fact that each branch of service has its own history of flight.

This is a great place for any age to go visit. They have an impressive museum of planes. They also have helicopters, flight uniforms through out the ages, and history of service women.
They have a gift store as well.

places_url_reviews_title: Plan on at least a half a day here!
places_url_reviews_comment: I try to make a visit every year during my annual ski trip to Utah. The Hill AFB museum is a great visit even if you’re not an aircraft or military enthusiast. The display of weapons is an eye opener. Once you see the size of the Gatling gun cannon that makes the A-10 “Warthog” the worlds best tank killer, I feel for those poor souls who happen to be on the ground when an A-10 comes calling. The SR-71 “Black bird” spy plane is also one of my favorite exhibits. Plan on spending at least a half of a day here to totally explore all of the indoor and outside exhibits.

places_url_reviews_title: Been here almost a dozen times - never gets old
places_url_reviews_comment: I love this museum. I love the people that work here and the retiree's that hang out and just want to chat. There are some really neat aircraft here and tons of history. What a great place!

I recently visited this museum with a friend of mine who is a pilot. He had flown many of the aircraft in the museum including several of the old warbirds. Touring this facility with him was an amazing experience. Many of the older veterans who volunteer here began to join us as they realized he had first hand information on these planes. The variety of aircraft here is very impressive, and even if you know little about aviation or history, this museum is worth a visit.

Really worth visiting if you are interested in aviation and/or military items. Great displays, high quality aircraft-the whole museum is very well thought out and care taken by those who have produced it. It is worth going out of your way to visit the museum-the active Hill AFB is further down the road. Excellent shop.

Hill Aerospace Museum is one of the must see places for our grandchildren when they visit every summer. Seeing the planes up close and reading the related history gives them hours of entertainment while learning about this branch of our country's military and their service to the country.

This is an interesting large museum. There is no charge but donations are accepted. They have a large amount of interesting aircraft, etc. I do wish you could go inside some of them. It is not a very interactive museum but it was nice.

I've lived in this area for over 15 years and had never visited this museum until this summer. I must say, I was shocked at the size of the buildings and the amount of planes on display. Everything was very close up and labeled so that you knew what it was. The museum is nicely laid out and there are even mannequins in period costumes around some of the exhibits. The thing I found most interesting, oddly enough, wasn't a plane, it was a display on Vietnam POWs. They had a replica of a cell at the Hanoi Hilton, along with stories of men who'd served at Hill Air Force Base before (or since) being captured in Vietnam. It was a very interesting story and I enjoyed the way that display was set up very much. I'm not sure I'd give this an overly enthusiastic recommendation for children. My daughter (10) was entertained for about an hour, but after that, she was wanting to leave.

The museum will take you back in history to WWII and the type of aircraft that were available. It will also show you the advances through these aircraft to modern day flight.
It is not a guided tour, so you have the leisure to take your time and read about the aircraft as you wish.
There are also volunteers through-out that are happy to answer your question.
You will also find a souvenir shop in the event you might want a keepsake.

The Hill Aerospace Museum is located on approximately 30 acres on the northwest corner of Hill Air Force Base, about five miles south of Ogden. The museum was founded in 1981 as a part of the United States Air Force Heritage Program and first opened in 1986. It moved to its current facility in 1991.
The Museum exhibits more than 90 military aircraft, missiles, and aerospace vehicles on the grounds and inside the Major General Rex A. Hadley Gallery and the Lindquist Stewart Fighter Gallery.
The list of aircraft on display is extensive. The collection also includes a wide variety of ordnance and munitions, an assortment of aerospace ground equipment, rockets, military vehicles, uniforms, and thousands of other historical artifacts.
We highly recommend a visit to the museum for aviation enthusiasts, and anyone with an interest in vintage aircraft and the United States Air Force history. It truly is an incredible facility well worth visiting.
It is conveniently located just off I-15 at Exit 338, Roy Exit. A gate pass onto Hill AFB is NOT required to visit the museum. Simply take Exit 338 (east) off Interstate 15 in Roy, Utah, and enter the museum grounds through the gate.
Also housed in the museum is an extensive, well-stocked gift shop. Food service is not provided onsite.
Parking and admission is free.
On our last visit in May of 2013, we spent nearly three hours in the museum. But the exhibits are so extensive and well done, that one could easily spend an entire day, and not see everything.
We did not know the museum existed and found it by chance. A great piece of American history. Wonderful that they work on donations only and give all a chance to visit.

I thought that the museum would be the planes sitting outside but was I fooled. They had 2 large hangars packed with planes. Has to be one of the great aviation musuems around. Oh, did I mention it was free, with lots of free parking, and also just over the interstate. You can spend the better part of the day here. We happened to be there on a Wednesday when the teaching center for kids was open. OK, so I'm a long way from being a kid but they let me try out the F-16 simulator. Can't say enough about this museum. Highly recommended!

I visit aircraft museums whenever available in each city we travel to during our summer Odysseys. This is one of the finer displays of aircraft in the intermountain west. Very well done with an abundance of volunteers to assist with any questions that may arise. Well worth the visit.

I have been air museums around the country and this one has to be in the top two. Most of the displays are in two large air conditioned buildings with a huge number of great volunteers to help you and tell you about each display. I was very impressed with condition of the aircraft as most look like they just came off the factory floor. Be prepared to spend several hours as there is so much to see for adults and children. I will definitely go back and spend time learning about the history of the aircraft. This museum is free and supported by donations and some help from the military. One of the highlights of my recent trip to Utah.

So, this was my husband's choice of event as he is really into planes and helicopters etc. I tagged along expecting to be bored but I was amazed by the diversity of displays and information available. OK, so I wasn't converted into being an 'aviation groupie' but I did enjoy all the 'human factor' and the insight into the WASPS, code breakers and the Vietnam POWs; very humbling in this day and age. A very well maintained and informative attraction that will appeal to everyone in the family.

We were looking for something different for my son's 4th birthday and found this to be the perfect place. We enjoyed reading about all of the planes and seeing them there right before us. I learned so much more about our country's history as well by reading about the fights and battles that some of these planes were used in. We also had the chance to meet a Veteran that absolutely made my son's day! Thank you for providing such a great place with some amazing people running it!

This is one of the best Aerospace museums I have visited. I have been to this museum a few times. They are always updating and improving. They have three indoor hangers with a replica of the Wright Brothers plane up to some of the most recent war planes. They also have a picnic tables outside and more planes outside. It is free but donations are accepted.

places_url_reviews_title: Dang cool if you like that kind if thing
places_url_reviews_comment: If you like military airplanes and jets... This is the place for you. The musem has a large number if different aircraft on display both outside and inside. The staff are volenteers who have many interesting stories to tell.

places_url_reviews_title: Excellent collection of vintage air raft
places_url_reviews_comment: If you are a lover of aircraft, this is the museum for you. Situated at the periphery of Hill Air Force Base in Layton, Utah, this museum has an extensive collection of aircraft, starting with earliest flights until late 20th century. The planes are arranged in chronological order and many are accompanied by recorded descriptions, photos and videos. The entrance fees are low, and during the summer several free days are available. Our young grandsons enjoyed this museum.

If you're into aircraft, this is the place to go.
It's free too.
Inside and outside exhibits.
Very educational. Well laid out. Plan on a few hours to absorb everything. Maybe longer.
One of the best attraction in Utah.
Also consider visiting Union Station, a few miles north, where there's a railroad museum, the John Browning firearms museum, an old car museum, and a tiny art museum, all for one small fee. Plus a restaurant serving the world's best Cobb Salad.

places_url_reviews_title: A Gem for Aircraft and History Buffs
places_url_reviews_comment: We did not know about this museum until we passed it on the highway. We were pleasantly surprised to find out there was no admission fee. We were even more surprised at the extensive collection of aircraft. Don't miss this place if you are a lover of history or aircraft.

places_url_reviews_title: Wonderful if you are into planes
places_url_reviews_comment: Fabulous collection of military planes, helos, uniforms, pictures, etc. I went with a friend who is into planes and he loved it; since I don't know much about them it was interesting but a little overwhelming. However definitely worth the trip, and it's free (donations much appreciated) and a good reminder of what sacrifices have been made for our freedom.

I have been to this museum several times and continue to find new things to see. The planes and materials are very realistic and well presented. They show what has been used to protect our freedom in the several wars.

If you enjoy seeing airplanes and jets, and the history of military planes and equipment you won't want to miss seeing this Museum. It is fantastic and the kids love it too! There are several displays that you won't want to miss. Have been several times and always enjoy seeing the new attractions.

The free admission is surprising considering what they have in this museum. Some of the highlights are the B-17, B-24, P-38, Sr-71, and P-47. Also, make sure to see the uniform display. Outside there is an aging B-29, C-130, C-119, and lots more. It is defeniatley worth your time.

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to spend some family time!
places_url_reviews_comment: I've taken my own children, cub scouts, and school groups to the Aerospace Museum. The kids are fascinated by the exhibits (most of which are airplanes dating from WWII and later) and by the docents. The volunteers are all retired airmen who have loads of personal stories about the aircraft and about their service. The kids especially love being able to get in the cockpit and see the controls! When my grandchildren are old enough, I'll take them too!

This is a great place to visit. you can wander around and look at the different planes. they usually have a vet there to get experiences of the war(s) they were in. You can spend as much time as wanted there.

The Hill Aerospace Museum, located on Hill Air Force Base, Utah, south of Ogden, Utah was founded in 1981 as a part of the United States Air Force Heritage Program and first opened in 1986, moving to its current location in 1991.
The museum has more than 90 military aircraft, missiles, and aerospace vehicles on the grounds and inside the Major General Rex A. Hadley Gallery and the Lindquist Stewart Fighter Gallery. The collection also includes a wide variety of ordnance and munitions, an assortment of aerospace ground equipment, military vehicles, uniforms, and thousands of other historical artifacts.
The very well stocked gift shop is part of the facility but no food services are present. An excellent all-round museum, focusing of USAF aircraft but very much a top museum in every respect.

places_url_reviews_title: Little (and big) boys will love to see the planes
places_url_reviews_comment: A great summary of the history of the Air Force and Hill Air Force Base specifically. There were interactive areas for the kids and enough variety to keep them interested. Reasonably priced.

places_url_reviews_title: Fantastic, as long as you like military aircraft and hardware
places_url_reviews_comment: The Hill Air Force base museum is truly fantastic. The variety and volume of aircraft that they have is somewhat surprising considering where this facility is located. The museum recently started a dedicated display for the Vietnam conflict to compliment the one that they already have for the Korean war. Both display's are tremendous and offer detail and information that is hard to find, unless you are a war historian. On a personal side, my wife's late grandfather flew bombers in WWII, and was a volunteer guide at this museum for many years. Having him take us through the museum describing his actions and memories with some of these aircraft during his service was incredible. The museum often has volunteers that do this same thing for anyone who comes through. Do your self a favor and ask the front desk about it. You will be glad that you did. I can't recommend this highly enough.
Airplanes of almost every description. Great for those who are interested in military aircraft. A lot of walking on cement.

Great place to visit if you enjoy old and modern military planes. It's also nice to visit on a hot day because the first hall is air conditioned. There are lots of interesting displays with associated text, so I learned a lot of things about WWII and the Korean war that I never knew about. The best part is that it's free!

places_url_reviews_title: A Must See For the Aircraft Enthusiast
places_url_reviews_comment: A great museum. If you are interested in US military airpower particularly from the Viet Nam era this place is a must see.

Don't miss this. We go back nearly every time we're near. One of the best collections of aviation history in the nation and a great facility. Children's hands-on center is awesome as well. Run by donations and volunteers to put a wad of cash in the donation box up front please!
This is great place to visit with family and kids. Great litlle history lesson. So much fun - Lots to see and knowledgeable volunteers

What can I say. I was in Ogden for a conference. During our off-time, the organizer arranged for our group to visit the Hill AFB Museum. I have 1 complaint...we only had 2.5 hours...I could have spent all day here. Great stories and photos to support the aircraft on display. This is a great destination for history buffs and aviation enthusiasts.
Go and take lots of pictures.

Indoor and outdoor exhibits of retired aircraft, US Navy Gear. Very impressive and surprisingly packed with objects I have only read about in newspaper. Museum does a very good job of explaining the context each of the exhibit items were used.
My favorite part was deatiled description and recreation of Hanoi Hilton Prison.
A high quality visit. Staff is clearly not just people who look at this as a job- very passionate.
I assumed it to be a 15 minutes stop- took about 2 hours instead.

Waited about 20 years to finally see the museum since moving here!!!
It was FANTASTIC!!!!
So many planes, so much history!!!
Loved reading all the stories of the people who made flights etc.
Seeing everything like uniforms and the actual items from the wars was so great!!!!
There is a lot of history in this place.
The Planes outside are awesome to look at and read about too!!!
Kudos to all the people that keep this place open for the public.
Really enjoyed it!!!

places_url_reviews_title: This was an excellent FREE exhibit
places_url_reviews_comment: There were so many more airplanes than I would have imagined, along with many great side exhibits and explanations. I highly recomment.

Not a lot of people will be able to go out to the Air and Space Museum in Washington D.C. and so this little museum is a fun alternative. It’s a great place to let your kids get up close and personal to some great aircraft.

This museum is very well done. There are two large buildings full of historic aircraft that are nicely restored. The staff are very knowledgable and happy to share information. There are also static displays outdoors in various states of repair.

places_url_reviews_title: Fun place to get up close with aircraft you usually only see on TV
places_url_reviews_comment: Nice collection of military aircraft. Free admission. Both inside and outside displays. Take your camera and share your photos with anyone you know who was in the military.

places_url_reviews_title: A Very Nice Collection and fun place to visit
places_url_reviews_comment: FREE! This place would be well worth the price of $5 or $10 admission, but its a great bargain at $free!

The HUGE planes in the yard are just. Awesome! It was cool to look at all the planes. Also, while we were there a young man named Jeremiah was teaching the kids how to make rockets out of paper and then we went outside and shot them off! We ended up spending 3 hours at the Museum and then enjoyed a nice picnic under one of the planes outside. Such a great place to see history. I highly recommend anyone in the area to stop by this place. Did I mention its free to get in?

places_url_reviews_title: Best Museum of it's Kind in USA
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum is so full of extremely well organized, self-guided exhibits, real aircraft, etc. that you could spend all day there. And, there is no entry fee....just a requested donation. This is really second best only to the Smithsonian Air & Space museum, but this museum does not include aero-space. It is just so fantastic!
Do not try to just spend one hour there...it will not work. Love the place! The static displays outside coupled with what is inside is outstanding.

Excellent mix of aircraft, inside and outside, good selection of WW1 and WW2 aircraft, also many Helicopters and Jet age Craft all indoors. Plan to spend a few hours indoors and and hour walking around outdoors.

We were very surprised to find such an excellent museum in a small town in Utah, even one near a major Air Force Base.
The museum displays an array of aircraft spanning the history of Air Force, from its origins as the Army Air Corps in WWII to the present, from a B17 to a SR71Blackbird, one of the few on display anywhere.
In addition to planes, there are a number of informative exhibits featuring period specific uniforms and other information about the history of aviation.
This gem of a museum was a pleasant discovery and a great way to spend a morning or an afternoon in Layton. You will learn a lot about history and come away with a greater respect for the men and women who have served our nation over the years.

This mueseum was a great expirience I had with my sons. I learned a lot during this and it kept my sons entertained quite a bit. I would definetly reccomend getting a tour guide to help learn about the planes. I did like how they kept it very cleaned up and had interactive areas throughout the museum. There were always workers nearby that would gladdly help you with any questions that you might have had. You will definatly be able to keep your kids attention with all of the neat planes and information cases. This museum is fun fo all ages and will keep you entertained.

places_url_reviews_title: A Great Place to take family
places_url_reviews_comment: The museum is incredible - you can stand under an old bomber, look into a field ambulance, see the uniforms that were worn through history. We took our adult children and our young nephew and everyone enjoyed the museum. Don't miss it.
A great museum.. Recently refurbished and updated. Great displays and great selection of planes. A great time for families.

places_url_reviews_title: Took family and great planes to see
places_url_reviews_comment: We spent most of the day looking at the variety of planes and choppers. I showed the family the many I have ridden in and even one I got to fly for a short time. The folks there are terrific, especially Norm Nielson. Clean restrooms and I mean tons of displays!

We have gone twice. One on a regular day, and the second during an event. I recommend going on an event day. They have volunteers who are very knowledgeable. We learned a lot and the kids had a blast.

We have been coming to this museum for the past 15 years, and it just keeps getting better! They have expanded well over the years, always great exhibits, and people to ask for information. One of Utah's best kept secrets!
For a small town museum this is a great place. There is a good variety and lots of history that most places don't have the availability.
There is a lot of interesting aircraft and weapons new and old. Some great historical fighting planes as well.

This is a great little Air Force Museum. There are lots of interesting aircraft here and the curator is the best. He has a story about every aircraft that really makes the tour come alive. My husband had is AF retirement ceremony here and they were very organized and helpful.
Great history learning experience for both kids & adults. Good place to stage a photo session. Entrance is free but remember to donate.

places_url_reviews_title: Lived in Utah all my life. Can't believe I didn't know this was such a great place!
places_url_reviews_comment: You won't believe how many actual planes are displayed here. Be prepared for a walk. You walk into a building expecting one building, but it connected to another, and another. Each building is chock full of aircraft and displays of information. There are several planes outdoors as well. Just amazing, and my 7 year old girl was excited and running around pointing everything out. She now knows many things about WWI and WWII.

This is one of the countrys best air and space museums operated mostly on volunteer and donations. I have been there many times and there is always something new and interesting to see. Meet some of the oldtimers that remember working with these beatiful aircraft. Just off of I-15 North. Even if you have been here before you will see that it is more than a static display of a bunch of old airplanes. It is real history.. I love this place.

places_url_reviews_title: Variety of Older Air Force Aircraft
places_url_reviews_comment: Scenic area with airplanes and exhibits inside and outside, it's free just give a donation. It's really a very large area with helicopters, an F-15, F-16, F-4, helicopters, C-130, B-52, KC-135 outside.

I took my boys, along with the Scouts to the museum last summer and we all loved it. From the bombers and jets outside, to the fantastic items inside. I loved the old bi-planes and my favorite - the B-17! I think that the boys would have loved to stay longer, but we could only stay for 3 hours before we had to head back. Even then I think we saw more than enough. I think that a few trips would be very worthwhile - especially for anyone who has a love of historical and military aircraft.
I remember my first visit as a scout, where our scoutmaster took us up to a F-4 Phantom and proceeded to tell us stories of his time flying them in 'Nam'. Our recent experience was led by a volunteer from the airbase who was being deployed the next day. He was an actual pilot and the boys loved to hear him talk of his experiences.
We will be back soon

For a museum that only asks for a donation, this is a must for anyone on a budget. Full size airplanes for the kids to run around, who could ask for more. Don't miss the play area, the kids had a blast there. Recommend all ages.

Museum is on the North side of Hill ABF, but access is no problem. Well thought out exhibits. The outside static plane displays were interesting to get so close to.
Worth a visit for the history and airplane buff. Donations accepted.

The museum was established to commemorate Utah's significant contribution to the Air Force. The outdoor exhibit of large planes grabbed our attention as we drove by, so we doubled back to see what it was about. Much to our amazement, the indoor exhibits were even more striking. You can see aviation technology from the era of the Wright brothers up to the SR-71 spy plane, with a strong focus on military applications. Well worth the stop for this free museum!

Well worth if for an aircraft buff like me, and the general public too. It was the main reason I went to Utah.
Well restored A/C in side, some of the outdoor ones are a bit ratty. ( a common problem with
museum aircraft the world over.
Being free is a bonus when travelling on a budjet, so they got bigger donation from me.
I snuck around the back ( naughty me) and found still more aircraft. Please note, I'm not advocating doing this.
Well worth it.
I only got to see a small smattering of exhibits, because the museum closes at 4:30. I realize its a military installation, but the museum should keep business hours and be open till at least 5 or 6.
the kids had so much fun, the air show is great, and it's a great place to visit for free. They loved seeing the old planes and the model planes hanging from the ceiling.
Best thing is it's free. Lots for the kids to see and do. Flight simulator that keeps them entertained for as long as you let them!

My grandchildren really liked the museum, especially the interactive ones. They really enjoyed seeing all the different exhibits. I helped them to understand the different jets and other aircraft since I used to be in the Military and flew some of them.

they are very well served for this area. Husband,son, brother, nephew have been in the military and we are always interested in airplanes, since husband is a pilot. Would love to find a way to get husband a flight with a military jet. How do I get that accomplished?

This is actually a pretty amazing museum. Everything from huge bombers outside to a blackbird inside. Older classic planes to very modern tech. A total of scores of planes spread over an outside airfield and two large hangers. Pretty amazing that it's free.

Visited here with my retired Air Force Colonel Father-in-law. He was moved to tears as he reminisced his time in the service. The displays are truly remarkable. The whole museum is a welcome reminder of the service and sacrifice of our military. Next time you're driving past on I-15, stop for a visit. Well worth the time.

places_url_reviews_title: See the amazing history of American military aircraft up close and touchable
places_url_reviews_comment: Going from not flying at all to sending rockets to the moon and beyond has almost all happened during my lifetime. But military aircraft has largely been developed secretely surrounded by mystery, myths of Alliens, and unbelievable achievement. To be able to see examples of this development upclose and touchable is to me more exciting, thrilling, and inspiring than to watch the most are out and futuristic movie about air and space travel. Anything can be done in the movies through models, art work and computers. But what you see at the Hill Air Force Base Museum WE ACTUALLY DID. To see it makes one proud to be a member of the human race. I thank the people at Hill Air Force Base for assembling such a breath-taking array of these aircrafts, and organize and maintain them for us to see that WE REALLY DID IT! (I wonder what unbelievable "marvels" are on the drawing boards or evening being flight test as we marvel at what we see at this great museum. If you are even close the it, DON'T MISS IT!
This is a great museum! You can experience the exhibits up close and really get a feel for how large the planes and missiles are. Great for the young and old.
A pretty good collection and it's free! Can't go wrong for the price, the kids liked the planes, so overall great little stop.

places_url_reviews_title: A really nice museum definitely worth a visit.
places_url_reviews_comment: I have seen most of the really great ones (like WPAFB Dayton, OH, Duxford, England etc.) and this is a relatively small museum in comparison. Still, it is definitely worth a visit and the staff is very helpful. Send the ladies and girls shopping and you'll enjoy ... kids will also love it.
Great restoration job on aircraft inside the museum. Friendly volunteer personnel. Well organized. Nice Vietnam War section.

This is one of the best museums of this type we have visited. The is a large selection of planes and the history that is presented there is terrific. Hill has been a dynamic edition to the Air Force and there is a lot of history that I'm sure you would not know if you don't visit.
If you like miltary history and aircraft this is the place for you. We visit several times a year and the volunteers are the best.
It was very warm inside and there was a fast-talking fellow selling eyeglass cleaner and jewelry cleaner among the exhibits. Seemed very unfitting.
I went here to kill some time and had and walked around the planes outside. Very nice collection that allows you to get up close to each plane.

We visited Hill Air Force Base Museum with our two young kids and our friends with even younger kids. It was a great visit. The kids loved seeing the air planes and asked all kinds of questions about them. The large variety of air planes, many since the early days of flying, made it easy for them to see how air planes evolved and what they were used for.
Admission is free and it was very convenient to visit. We spent about 1 1/2 hours there.

places_url_reviews_title: The boys loved it! The girls... not so much.
places_url_reviews_comment:
My son is an airplane/military aficionado. This stop on our trip was completely for him (16). And he and my hubby loved it. My daughter (13) and I spent the time downloading photos into my laptop (we've had to do these stops before and, frankly, when you've seen one plane, you've seen them all if you're not interested in them).
Planes, planes, planes. I don't know the specific models, but the boys took lots of pictures. There aren't many places for the "significant others" to sit and wait. I think they spent about an hour and a half looking at the planes (we knew we were on a tight schedule, so they may have rushed through the museum thinking they might run out of time). The staff/volunteers seemed very knowledgable and even suggested another museum he may like. That was super helpful since I never know what to look for in these things.
We decided to wait in a room that was dark (to preserve the artifacts), cool and not as busy. Turned out it was a flight suit exhibit - those were interesting for us to look at.
Admission is free (or by donation).
Amazing collection of military airplanes with wonderful accessibility by public. Great for ages 3-103

places_url_reviews_title: Great Place for a Family Outing- Cool Airplanes!
places_url_reviews_comment: This place was pretty awesome! It has all kinds of retired military airplanes and the guys in our group especially found this place to be really cool :-) When you first walk in the museum seems quite small, but I was pleasantly surprised that there were two huge buildings attached holding the majority of the airplanes and engines. They also have an area sectioned off just for kids where they can try on old military aviation uniforms and sit in simulated cockpits and try their hand at flying. Overall, our whole group really enjoyed it. Even the little ones can roam around a little if you keep an eye on them. My only complaint is that the rooms wih the airplanes were so hot! We were really sweating! Other than that it was great and you can't beat the price, although I'm sure they appreciate donations. Running a museum like that can't be cheap.

My husband and I wanted to go to the Hill Aerospace Museum. That place was VERY interesting and lot of planes. We enjoyed it and it was FREE! And It was so cool to see the real Hitler's hat! Of course, We are not fan of him. God Bless America!!!
We came here for 'Grandma' day. The kids loved seeing the planes up close. We all had a great time! I'm sure we'll do it again.
Looking at the planes is cool. But then what??? Your only allowed see so much and then your bored to just walk back to the car.

Lots of volunteers to answer questions. Old fighters, cargo planes, helicopters trainers, and the best aircraft in the USAF: The Mighty KC-135 refueler, even though it's not the R model I flew, still impressive.

If you are interested in aircraft this is the place to go. We've visited several times over the years with our kids and grandkids and always take other visitors. My favorite display is the "Blackbird" SR-71. There is really a lot to see and more is added all the time. It's nice that it is a free museum.
Our entire family enjoys visiting the museum. There is history to see. There are interactive exhibits. Each time you visit you find something new.

places_url_reviews_title: great place in which to spent an afternoon
places_url_reviews_comment: ideal for any aero enthusiast and anyone who wants to learn more about U.S. involvement in wars and their perspective

This museum is large, well put together, and very interesting. Who could pass up the opportunity to see all these airplanes and such. It is right off I-15. There is a neat display of pilot gear and outfits too. The addition they made a few years back is full of remarkable aircraft including the SR-71 blackbird. There is over 4000 objects at the museum including aircraft, military vehicles, missiles, ordinance, military uniforms, artwork, and a nice code talker display. They have a gift shop also! Check it out!
Museum was very interesting, amazing facts for each exhibit, ! Well worth the drive out there.

The collection of aerospace items in this facility staffed by veterans will take alot of time that could not be better spent to see. Come early in the morning to see the static displays and then the hot portion of the day visiting the interior of the two buildings.
Fun place to take the kids. I learned lots of interesting facts about the Air Force.

The museum has become a family tradition. My son loved to go when he was a child and now he takes his children. We have been more times than I can count. They add new displays often. When we have out of town visitors, we love to take them here. Especially my uncles, both of whom are veterans. They really enjoyed it! It's well done and access is easy.

Great place to take the family and grandkids. They all loved it and wanted to go again and again. It is free (they accept donations) so it is very cost affordable. We all had a wonderful time each time we went.

This was my second visit to this museum, and I was pleasantly surprised to see that the outdoor collection had been sorted out and exhibited better than my first visit, but the majority of the outdoor collect desperately need to be repainted - they are looking pretty sad - these are mostly the Air Forces' heavy metal - the B-47, B-52, B-1, etc, plus a bunch of airliners which have had service lives.
Indoors there are two buildings linked - the first one features a few pre WW2 aircraft, but the bulk of the exhibits are WW2 plus Korean War planes - they tend to get in each others way, however, especially when it comes to photography - hard to get a clean shot of one aircraft - definate need for additional hanger space to be able to exhibit the collection better
The second building houses the more contemporary aircraft - somewhat better organized, but still crowded - there are some great exhibits, and I could see that they were working on more as I wandered around.
In general this is one of the better aircraft collections and well worth a visit - it also demonstrates a need for additional funding so that more buildings can be put in place so that the collection can be exhibited in a better way, and as I said, the outdoor collection needs a lick of paint.

Easy access off I-15, South of Ogden, UT at Hill AFB. Not as large as the National Museum of the U.S. Air Force at Wright-Patterson AFB near Dayton, OH, but it has a nice collection inside two connected buildings and outside on the tarmac. You can do a quick walk around in an hour or spend longer by reading the well done information signs. The outside aircraft are a bit shabby due to weathering, but you can get up close to enjoy and learn about USAF history & planes from WWII to now.

If you love aviation and war planes this is a must-see! Inside is everything from a model of the Wright Flier, a B-17 Flying Fortress, a Delta Dart,a SR-71 to an A-10 Warthog (Thunderbolt). Not to mention some of the "big guns" outside: B-52 and B-1. There is plenty to see and learn, give yourself a couple of hours. Plus, you can't beat the value: IT'S FREE!! (Donations are appreciated.)
Fun to see the planes up close and learn the history behind them.

places_url_reviews_title: Tons of planes to look at!
places_url_reviews_comment: It is super fun and my little boy has adored it since he was old enough to walk.
what a great place to learn about the Military and its fine men and women whom make it, you feel as if you where actually in the war. And the staff are the best, well worth the visit.

What a fantastic collection of Air Force aircraft. The museum has examples of fighter, bomber and transport aircraft from World War 11, Korea, Vietnam and current operational types. Unfortunately, we did not have time to have a thorough look at the museum due to time constraints - one could spend a few days there.

places_url_reviews_title: Great birthday present for young aviators
places_url_reviews_comment: We took my 10 year old son and his 2 best friends here for a great birthday. Each had a sketch pad and a pencil and they spent hours sketching favorite planes and helicopters. They have an SR-71 blackbird here. You can't beat that!

I have a two year old and he loves this place. We go about once a month. The volunteers are awesome and sometimes you can get a private tour if it isn't too busy. They have a children's explore area that is open on Saturdays. I highly recommend if you love planes and want to do something for free. I also recommend that you donate if you do go, they don't require an entrance fee and do this all on donations.

places_url_reviews_title: A must see while in Utah!
places_url_reviews_comment: My 11 year old is a history and war buff so he really wanted to go to this museum. My husband and I took him and my 2 adult children and we all thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. This museum was AMAZING!! It was much bigger than we expected and it is free. We loved all the great planes they have but all of the guns, missiles, uniforms and stories are amazing too. We spent hours looking through everything and we were so impressed! This is a must see in my book!

Not as extensive as the Air and Space Museum at Dulles airport in the DC area, but still lots of aeronautical history that has been maintained well. If you are a military airplane buff, it's worth visiting.

Unless you are an ex pilot or military,this is a kind of ho-hum experience. I have noticed that older guys really get nostalgic and start to tell stories,so in that respect its good. It involves a lot of walking and standing.
For a war history buff or someone into aerospace history this is a great place to visit.

places_url_reviews_title: If you like planes or USAF history
places_url_reviews_comment: Great place to spend an afternoon if the subject interests you.
A dream for any military airplane enthusiast! A definite recommend if you visit northern Utah.
Lots of interesting planes, great place to take kids to see military planes and learn about history.

places_url_reviews_title: Competes with the Air Force Museum in Dayton.
places_url_reviews_comment: A broad selection of classic airplanes and the price is right, free.

Large volume of aircraft and other exhibits on display.
Easy access to museum from I-15.
Very hospitable staff/volunteers who are ready, willing and able to answer any question.
Wished there was on-site dining available.

places_url_reviews_title: If you like airplanes, this is the place to visit.
places_url_reviews_comment: The planes cover a wide range of air travel. It is a very interesting place for someone interested in airplanes. The museum is free of charge, though donations are accepted.

places_url_reviews_title: Great for kids and plane folks
places_url_reviews_comment: Get it? If you want to know what pilots looked like decades ago just check out the uniforms and you'll want to know how the US became an obese nation. They're twigs! I have all due respect for our military and retired military, a Navy Captain who married us died a few weeks ago. But I've been to better military museums, I'm spoiled that way. This is a good one, and I hope that families who visit will remember veterans and lost soldiers.
free admission, great place to take the kids. Great selection of planes.
The KC-135E parked here is one that I flew for 11 years! Great variety of airplanes run by a volunteer staff that really cares about preserving them. Go!!
Many aircraft on display - up close and personal. Knowledgeable guides.

places_url_reviews_title: Engaging for Boys of every age
places_url_reviews_comment: This museum is a family favorite, for the boys in the family especially. The exhibits are large and very interesting, plenty of history if you are interested. If you're not a history buff, it's just as fun to walk around and see the planes.
I love the Aerospace Museum. It has always been a great place to visit. I go visit it every chance I get. Always plenty to see for everyone young and old alike.

places_url_reviews_title: Stretch your legs and see some Very cool Planes!!!
places_url_reviews_comment: It is a short stop and it is free. Kids will think it is really cool. Must see at least once if you are driving through from a long trip. See some cool planes and stretch the legs and your back on the road.

places_url_reviews_title: Nice museum showing vintgage military planes
places_url_reviews_comment: A lot of your experience will depend on how crowded it is and the skill of the volunteers working that day.

places_url_reviews_title: Make time to talk to the docents!
places_url_reviews_comment: Reportedly the second largest USAF museum (behind the main USAF Musuem in Dayton, OH), Hill AFB Museum offers plenty of see from the era of canvas and wood pioneer aircraft to the space age.
