Planes and missiles are always interesting, but when you visit, make sure you talk to the docents, most of whom are retired pilots. Their insights and experience bring an added dimension to the aircraft displays in the hangers and on outdoor display.

places_url_reviews_title: Pretty interesting and mostly indoors, nice!
places_url_reviews_comment: We were there in February and walked around through several buildings inside. Just a super bunch of variety of planes in here and worth a couple of hours of your time if you are visiting the area.
Great for everyone in the family, but the little boys and big boys really love it. There is so much to see and learn.
This is a good museum. Plenty to see and it is free!

places_url_reviews_title: Great place to take the kids...of any age.
places_url_reviews_comment: Great way to send half a day or less. I believe it was free...only asking for a donation.

We live near this museum and I have been taking my children (ages 7 and 5) here regularly for several years. This museum has two large hangars full of airplanes representing the history of flight from the Wright brothers to the F-16. Planes from all of the major wars in the last century are represented. There is also a large yard in front with many more planes to see up close. My grandpa piloted a B-24 in WWII and I like seeing that plane with my kids and sharing their history with them. The volunteers are friendly and knowledgeable. Best of all, there is no charge to enjoy the museum, though donations are gratefully accepted.
There is an Education Room in the back hangar where kids can play with science toys. It isn't open all the time, so check in advance if you want to be sure it will be open for your visit. For younger kids there are traditional toys and for older kids (and adults) there are flight simulators and computers. Once last summer a volunteer helped helped us make paper rockets that we then took outside and shot into the air.
Tripadvisor's Ogden address for this attraction threw me off a little. This museum is inside Hill Air Force Base, just west of I-15 near Roy, a smaller city just south of Ogden. You can easily see this museum from the freeway, especially if you are travelling from the south.

Full of planes from the Wright Brothers to modern day. Fun for the kids to explore and lots of facts for the grown-ups. There are planes in 2 different buildings along with planes outside. Tables under a few of the giant planes make for a great picnic spot. Also, inside there is a room dedicated to flight suits & uniforms from throughout the years.

places_url_reviews_title: Great planes, wonderful history of each war and local heroes.
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a great side trip. We took a break from skiing one afternoon and drove down. There are two buildings of planes and the ones outside. It is a great history lesson and we learned several new things. My teens had a great time!

This is an excellent museum with many aircraft. If you can find one of the museum volunteers to talk to, it will enhance your visit. The ones I have spoken with either worked on or flew the actual planes. They can tell you personal anecdotes which are interesting.

The Hill Air Force Base Aerospace museum is incredible! They have a huge assortment of military planes and paraphernalia on display and all of it is free. My boys especially liked the hands-on exhibits where they could suit up and fly the F-16 simulators. If you are a fan of military history and/or aviation in general, this is a must see!

We went to Hill Aerospace Museum the last day of our trip. Don't miss this amazing museum. There are two huge rooms full of planes and information. Outside they have an assortment of planes you can walk around. Plan a few hours for this museum to really enjoy it. Plus they have an excellent hands on area for children.

A very nice aerospace museum convenient to Salt Lake City that is FREE. They have a great collection of planes and other artifacts plus a great collection of stories of locals that have influenced the aerospace since World War I.

Went here for about an hour while guys went golfing. I do not know much about planes, but was very impressed with this museum. First of all, there was no admission, only donations. There are planes on display outside, then in 2 warehouse like areas inside full of more. Could have easily spent more time here (picnic benches outside under/around planes on a nice day would make for a nice lunch spot;)). If you are I the area or passing by, hope you have time to go and make a donation to this great display.

places_url_reviews_title: Roy exit, not Ogden. A Must See! Free and amazing
places_url_reviews_comment: I have been to about every airplane museum in America and also in Europe and I rate the Hill AFB museum in the top three. It is free, free parking, right off the Roy exit on I15. I don't get where they say this is Ogden. An amazing array of aircraft that is not just air force. You have replica Wright flyers all the way up to current F-16's with everything in between including a C124 and B24. There are vets or free tour guides to ask any questions and a fun gift shop. Watch the movies and spend the day. There are plenty of eating aces within three to five minutes away. Plan a trip and spend the day.

The exhibits outside are great. Being able to catch some shade underneath a B-52 bomber is pretty amazing... Be sure and save time for the inside and speak with some of the exhibit volunteers. These folks have an amazing number of years experience and knowledge. The person I spoke with was a former NASA dude who had helped rebuilt/restore part of a B-17 console. Cheers

places_url_reviews_title: Can't go to the Smithsonian? GO HERE.
places_url_reviews_comment: This is a tremendous air museum. Warplanes from all air wars are displayed from a Wright brother's replica to a SR-71 Blackbird. Over 50 planes are displayed. Of particular interest is a display of Jimmy Doolittle's raid on Tokyo and an in depth movie of the making and history of the SR-71. The displays also include the Utah Air Force Hall of Fame with fascinating stories of heroism. Allow 1 to 2 hours.

Hill AFB museum is free! Outdoor display included several F-4 Phantoms, B-1B, B-52, plus many others that you can walk up to and touch! Such heroes flew these planes. The indoor museum was HUGE and included an SR-71 (our favorite) plus MANY others. There are also many old fly-boys hanging around to answer your questions....very interesting to talk to them! Great gift shop offering many models, books, t-shirts, kid's toys, all at very reasonable prices....a must-see for a family vacation!

places_url_reviews_title: If your in the Ogden area, a must see
places_url_reviews_comment: We stopped here expecting not to see much because it was free, but being free figured we couldn't lose. They have a huge selection of plans both inside & outside. My husband is a history/military buff & couldn't believe they had several rare planes he had never seen before. It blows away even the Smithsonians collection & the local ones we have in WA & OR. Stop you won't regret it. Oh, & easy on & off the freeway!

places_url_reviews_title: very extensive Air Force museum north of Salt lake City
places_url_reviews_comment:
Hill Air Force Base Museum is conveniently located on Interstate 15 about 35 miles north of Salt Lake City. For anyone interested in military aircraft, the Museum displays a very large collection of U.S. Air Force aircraft from about 1940 to 2000.
The collection includes famous aircraft from the Cold War period including the B-52, B-47, F-102, F-4, C-124, and many others. The collection includes notable World War II aircraft inculding the B-29, B-24, B-17, P-40, P-51, P-47, and P-38.
The large aircraft are displayed outdooors, where they unfortunately show the effects of weather. Smaller and fully-restored aircraft are displayed inside two large air-conditioned buildings where they are well protected but unfortunately parked so close to one another it is sometimes difficult to fully appreciate the aircraft. There are a large number of displays of missles, aircraft engine cut-aways, etc. Admission is free. Access to the Museum is very convenient, because it is adjacent to, but not enclosed in, the active Air Force Base, so there are no difficult admission procedures.
One of the most interesting displays focuses on women pilots who served in World War II, mainly ferrying aircraft. I was surprised and saddened to learn that many of these women faced a great deal of hostility from male fliers, mechanics, etc. It is sad that people had time for that pettiness while trying to fight such a major war.

My husband and I took our 9 year old son here on September 2, 2007 while en route from Brigham City to Salt Lake City. The museum is located by the Hill Air Force base. Our son is very interested in World War II and military aircraft. He very much enjoyed the museum as did myself and my husband!
This museum houses dozens of renovated military aircraft, from the Wright Flyer to WWII planes and newer jet fighters such as an F-15 and a Blackbird. There are indoor and outdoor exhibits (the larger planes are located outdoors, such as the B-52 bomber). The complete listing of aircraft is on the museum's website. Outside we also saw aircraft landing at the Air Force base which was cool.
There are informative displays about each aircraft and even a small military uniform display. Volunteers are on staff to provide insight about the various aircraft. Since my son appeared very into the museum we were given a very thorough tour of the museum by two volunteers, which we enjoyed very much and found very informative.
The museum and parking are free and open 7 days a week. I would definitely recommend this museum to military aircraft and history enthusiasts.
